content: @Mediavenir Grand merci Ã  lui. Il aura mÃ©ritÃ© un billet premiÃ¨re classe sur Air France pour son vol de retour vers bamako.

I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed our version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.
author_description: early access to the future of chess: https://t.co/4dBkUp3B02

content: @yellmapper Worth more than gold. https://t.co/c0F8HCILQ9 QT @Tendaijoe: In 1987, Steven Rothstein bought a lifetime â€œAAirpassâ€ from American Airlines for $250,000, which allowed him to fly first class anywhere in the world, with an additional $150,000 option to bring a companion. Rothstein was one of several people who purchased these passes during a time when American Airlines was looking for quick capital due to financial struggles. The airline had anticipated that buyers would use the tickets moderately, but Rothstein took full advantage, flying over 10,000 times and reportedly costing the airline around $21 million in total. American Airlines eventually terminated his pass in 2008, accusing him of fraudulent behavior, such as booking flights for strangers as his companions and making excessive last-minute reservations. Rothstein disputed the airlineâ€™s claims, but his pass was canceled.

content: Back in January week I NEEDED to fly back to Philadelphia to pack my ski bags (at my parents home) for a quick 48 hour turnaround time to get to the Canada Rockies on Jan 10th. My goal was to fly from Spain either the 7th or 8th, and I thought it may be tricky because plane loads are still heavy from Europe back to US post holiday season. No matter, I set my trusty seatsDOTaero text alert for MAD/BCN -> PHL (American Airlines is the only carrier that flies direct and they are notoriously hard to book with). I thought that there was a chance Alaska would list 1 or 2 biz class seats for this route, even though the Expert Flyer seat maps were showing very full. That being said, I also set alerts for all of Europe back to Philadelphia, and I was fully prepped to take a positioning flight from Spain to a Major EUR airport to catch the flight back. LOW AND MOTHER FCKING BEHOLD, I got an alert text this morning that there is 1 biz class seat open on Etihad (AA partner) for 80,000 points, direct to Philly! But hold on there, I know thanks to the Alliance and Transfer Partner sheet we have inside Phantom Community, Alaska is also a partner with AA and Etihad. So I run a manual check, and boom. 55,000 point biz class. This isn't rocket science. Most of the time when a partner airline such as Etihad is showing availability, others will too. The reason Alaska is better of course, is their biz class partner flights are priced AMAZINGLY, and its refundable if you need to cancel or change your date. No brainer. Did the clutch Amex - Hawaiian -> Alaskan transfer and called it a day. $4,250 flight for 55,000 pts, a nice $0.08 per point redemption. As always, if this seems complicated to you, feel free to ask anything below or shoot me a DM.

content: British Airways and the City of Joburg: Same Failure, Just 35,000 Feet Apart Last week, British Airways cancelled my flight. I wasnâ€™t surprised. The signs were there, I even flagged it to them in advance. Their response? â€œWeâ€™ll deal with it if it happens.â€ And when it did, they failed. UK Regulation 261 is crystal clear: when an airline cancels your flight, they must rebook you in comparable conditions at the earliest opportunity â€” even if that means putting you on a rival carrier. BA offered me two entirely unsuitable options, then left me to fight for what the law already guarantees. I spent 45 minutes on the phone with an agent who outright lied to me â€” claiming UK261 â€œdoesnâ€™t apply,â€ that I didnâ€™t understand the law, and that he couldnâ€™t book me on non-partner airlines. Twice I asked to speak to a manager. Twice I was brushed off. And then â€” suddenly â€” a suitable Lufthansa flight was found. Nothing changed in the law. Just their willingness to follow it. This is what British Airways has become: a company that charges premium fares, then treats customers with disdain. Theyâ€™ve gutted their customer service, monetised every element of the experience, and now hide behind policy to deny even basic accountability. You pay for first-class values and receive budget airline behaviour. And that same broken model â€” high input, zero output, maximum deflection â€” is exactly what weâ€™re living through in Johannesburg. Yesterday, the MMC for Finance delivered the Cityâ€™s budget speech. And while the language was polished, the subtext was clear: the suburbs have had their turn. Future investment, she implied, must now go elsewhere. There was no mention of the reality on the ground â€” that suburban infrastructure in Johannesburg hasnâ€™t seen serious investment in over 30 years. That our water systems are decaying. That our substations are overloading. That roads and pavements are breaking down. Instead, the ANC-deployed cadres running the Cityâ€™s finances speak as if these communities are already being "served" â€” and should now simply keep paying more for less. This is the core issue: the very residents who fund the City are treated not as stakeholders, but as cash cows. There's no reciprocity. No fairness. Just rising rates, degrading service, and a cold political message: â€œYouâ€™ll survive. Others need more.â€ In both systems â€” British Airways and the City of Johannesburg â€” we see the same pattern. The people keeping the system afloat are treated with disdain. Theyâ€™re expected to pay up â€” premium rates, premium fares â€” for zero value. And any hope of accountability has vanished. Whether you're a flyer or a ratepayer, your loyalty is exploited, not respected. Letâ€™s not pretend this is sustainable. You donâ€™t save an airline by cutting the engines and handing out blankets to the passengers in the back. And you donâ€™t save a city by gutting the parts that still function just to prop up the parts that have collapsed. British Airways has already been voted the worst long-haul airline by Which? Magazine â€” a clear sign that passengers are waking up. Theyâ€™re becoming irrelevant, not because of market forces, but because of their own decisions. Johannesburgâ€™s government is following the same path. But thereâ€™s one key difference: unlike airline executives, political leaders can be replaced. And they will be. The ANCâ€™s grip on Johannesburg is slipping. People are seeing through the blame. Through the arrogance. Through the deliberate neglect. When the next local elections come â€” in 2026 or 2027 â€” they will not be the biggest party in this city. Because people have had enough. We are not the problem. We are not selfish for expecting service in return for what we pay. And we will no longer accept a system that punishes sustainability while rewarding collapse. Thatâ€™s not equity. Thatâ€™s decay. And it's time to change course â€” before this city, too, falls out of the sky. (Daniel Schay - 29 May 2025)
author_description: DA Shadow MMC of Development Planning in Johannesburg, Ward 72 Councillor. Father, husband, civil engineering technologist, activist

content: Well holy shit. My flight from JFK to LAX is way oversold and every seat is taken. To get as many people on the plane as they can they moved people from biz class to first class. They also needed to move people from coach to biz to get some of the oversold people on the plane. As I was getting ready to board they handed me a new ticket because I was upgraded to biz class. Cannot fully express how happy I am. Iâ€™ve taken so many flights the past few days and being able to lay down on this late night flight is a dream come true. Thank you American Airlines for the upgrade and also for fixing the worldwide tech issues so fast so I could get out of Paris yesterday and make the Deadpool and Wolverine junket today.

content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. Bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown alot this year, and while I don't enjoy the 16+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlines

content: I've been musing about the changes to the British Airways "Club" from my cabin here in the Yukon. Clearly this was inevitable. With the change to Avios earning being revenue based, this was always going to happen, it was simply a question of when, and how bad the change was going to be. I am struck though by how 'Delta' like the changes are. Perhaps BA/IAG have grown a pair and figured given their network and fortress hub position at LHR, people will fly them regardless, so tough cookies to all of their customers. I think perhaps the trans-Atlantic joint-business had some input into it too, as clearly it was much harder to get status for an EXP or CK than it was Gold or GGL given the hard spend requirements for Loyalty Points. The sad thing is, I think BA may actually be right about people sticking with them. Look at the Lufthansa Group for example. Lufthansa business class is rubbish. Swiss is ok. Coupled with the fact that Miles & More (unless you're HON Circle), is pretty mediocre, and certainly not as good as the Exec Club was, yet people still fly Lufthansa Group because they and United/Air Canada offer non-stop products in the markets with which they serve. Miles & More's switch to a points based system took some elements of the BA programme, but didn't take any of the gamification of the Exec Club that enables tier point running. So it's somewhat of a half-way house and therefore not as engaging. My predictions for 2025 are that BA and IAG will largely stay the course for this one. However I do predict some kind of mid-year tier point credit (perhaps July/August time), like Lufthansa did, when it's clear that fewer people will requalify. However I don't think there will be a significant impact to bookings. The 'US3' and to some extent the Lufthansa changes show us that people will stick with them regardless. So more heat than light for probably longer than people expect, but no big impact to the IAG FY results in 2025.

content: Save this for when I am rich soon. https://t.co/P0Xv6s3LFf QT @hxxntrr: sat next to a guy in business class to tokyo asked what he does "i fly 30 times a year for FREEâ€ thought he worked for an airline nopeâ€¦ he figured out American airlines points are fucking BROKEN if you stack them right now I havenâ€™t paid for flights in years Here's what he showed me: The airline points game is rigged in your favor if you know which cards to stack and which portals to abuse American Airlines miles are the cheat code for international travel and almost nobody uses them correctly Here's the play: AA miles transfer 1:1 to partners like Qatar, Cathay Pacific, Japan Airlines. A business class seat to Asia that costs $8,000 cash? 70,000 miles. That's worth $0.11 per point when you redeem smart Now here's where it gets unethical: Every online purchase you make should go through the AA shopping portal first. Best Buy, Nike, Walmart, Apple - they're all on there. You're getting 2-15x miles on purchases you were making anyway $5,000 in normal spending = 25,000+ bonus miles = free domestic flight But the real players stack it: Open Citi AA Business card (80k bonus miles after $4k spend) Open Barclays AA Business (50k bonus miles) Run all business expenses through portal Pay suppliers through cards before liquidating Within 6 months you're sitting on 200,000+ miles without trying I know a guy who hasn't paid for a flight in 4 years. Books business class to Europe twice a year for "work trips" that are actually just vacations. Puts clients on economy while he's sipping champagne in the front The points cost him nothing. The flex is priceless Most people earn miles and let them expire. Or redeem them for toasters like idiots. Or fly economy when the same miles could get them flatbed seats Stop flying like you're broke when credit card companies are literally begging to send you to Bali for free

content: @PauloNoggy This itinerary isn't a saver route; it's to maintain my gold status for another two years. In the long run, I benefit from free upgrades, first class check-in even when flying economy, lounge access (including the Concorde Room and First Class Lounge even when flying economy), unlocking preferred seats on certain routes, free seat selection across all oneworld airlines(which for Qatar in biz can cost Â£75 per seat), and free 2 x 32kg baggage allowance for me and everyone I book for, regardless of class, on all airlines. These perks save me a lot overall and can be used with any oneworld airline, not just British Airways. The itinerary cost me Â£340, with two of the flights costing just Â£1 each and the rest paid for with Avios. I also took advantage of the BA sales that ended yesterday.

content: An American Airlines flight from Las Vegas to Dallas turned chaotic when a flight attendant suddenly locked herself in the galley and called police on multiple first-class passengers mid-flight. Shocked travelers say the confrontation started over simple drink requests that spiraled out of control. Before takeoff, the pilot had already warned passengers that â€œno rudeness toward flight attendants would be tolerated,â€ setting an oddly tense tone for Flight AA3286. Once in the air, service in first class was delayed for more than an hour while those in economy had already been served, frustrating passengers who say they had done nothing wrong. The bizarre incident happened on October 4th, 2025, aboard an Airbus A321 headed for Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW). Witnesses say the flight attendant became defensive and accused a passenger of reporting her to the captain, which he denied. She then told the captain that customers were â€œmean,â€ â€œbelligerent,â€ and â€œprobably drunk,â€ before locking herself in the galley and refusing to continue service. When the plane landed, she read up to ten passenger names over the PA system, announcing that police would meet them at the gate. Officers did meet the plane but reportedly laughed after hearing what happened and left without taking action. Police later advised airline staff not to use law enforcement as a threat toward passengers. American Airlines has since confirmed an internal investigation is underway.

content: I had my best event ever in 2021 after a messy trip and posted about it (below). Then my mentor sent me a message: "The harder the journey, the better the tournament." It was indeed like that! I reached the top 16 in the World Cup and had some amazing games. July 6, 2021 My trip to Sochi with United was the most ridiculous travel experience ever that I would like to rant about it so it is out of my system. 1. I buy a ticket to Sochi directly from United Airlines on June 20. 2. I receive an email from United airlines about the need to call them urgently on June 23. I call and learn that part of my flight from Frankfurt is canceled. So we look for alternatives for 40 minutes. We get the exact same ticket at the end! 3. 5 hours before my flight on July 4, I see on the United app that some part of the flight from Frankfurt is not shown. Therefore, I get suspicious and call United customer care. I am told sorry your flight is canceled and you should have received an email about that. (But I did not!) Another 40-50 minutes looking for alternatives and I get the exact same ticket again! 4. Check-in takes forever in St.Louis airport to tag my luggage till Sochi. I clarify if I need to pick up my luggage in Moscow or not, but I am assured that I do not. (Anyway, I did check in Moscow, and it was on the luggage ramp!). I only get my boarding pass till Chicago and am supposed to get the rest of the passes from Lufthansa at Chicago airport. 5.I finally approach the Lufthansa gate at Chicago airport after a long line to hear that I do not have a ticket! I try to talk to the agent and explain that I just got my ticket 5 hours ago, and this is my itinerary. She cuts me off by saying do not waste any time and go to the United customer care and get help because little time left till the flight. 6.I run to United customer care and they literally give me the same thing that I was going to show to that agent and send me back. I run back and show these things to a different agent, but this time she does issue a boarding pass for Chicago-Frankfurt-Moscow. . My Moscow-Sochi boarding pass is not issued. 7. I decide to check-in online for my flight for Moscow-Sochi at Frankfurt airport. S7 Airlines says my flight is not found. I contact United customer care again and they say yes, it is canceled. (no notification again!) The next flight tomorrow at 8 am. And of course, accommodation till tomorrow is not covered. 8. Anyway, I prefer to buy a ticket from a different airline which is flying approximately the same time that my canceled flight. Guess what happens next? 9.I arrive at my gate and see the supposedly canceled flight is happening at the next gate! I added the photo of the â€œcanceled flightâ€. QT @HansMokeNiemann: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed our version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.
author_description: Chess Grandmaster. Founder @chesseverapp

The flight, operated by an Airbus A321, began with the captain warning that â€œno rudenessâ€ toward crew would be tolerated. According to passengers in first class, service was delayed for over an hour while economy had already been served. Tensions escalated when the lead flight attendant accused passengers of being â€œmeanâ€ and â€œbelligerent,â€ before locking herself in the galley and refusing to continue service. She told the captain she would â€œcall the unionâ€ and then announced over the PA that police would meet specific passengers at arrival, even reading out their names. At Dallas/Fort Worth, officers met the aircraft but reportedly laughed after hearing the passengersâ€™ side of the story. Police later advised American Airlines staff not to use law enforcement as a threat. The airline confirmed it is investigating the incident, adding that its â€œgoal is to provide a positive travel experience.â€ Several passengers were contacted after the flight, with some offered compensation. Industry observers argue the episode highlights deeper issues with crew training and culture at American Airlines, where reports of inconsistent service have become more frequent. Analysts say the airline needs stronger leadership, clearer standards, and accountability to prevent future onboard conflicts.

content: @OrlandoTaxus @RepJeffries So you want to say that hiring air traffic controllers under DEI that are not as qualified as some others will not cause accidents? Look at what just happened with the Black Hawk and American Airlines collision. Was the air traffic controller a DEI hire? It sure was not because of the hiring freeze by Trump. Don't you want to feel safe when flying? I do. I fly several times a year. Do you know how many planes have been grounded? Do you know how many mechanical issues I've had while flying to where they had to bring another plane? We were in vegas for my daughter's wedding and they went home in first class. The inner window was cracked, the plastic under the window was cracked all the way down to the ground. Guess what happened a few weeks later? A cracked window blew out of an SW airlines plane and the passenger was partially sucked out, she died. That could have been my daughter. We should not be hiring based on quotas we should hire based on skill...period. This is a temp. freeze, hiring will resume with qualified controllers.

content: @DebNonCompliant Hey Deb, American Airlines Passenger Tackled After Attempting to Breach Cockpit on Brazil-to-NY Flight Name: Unknown (female passenger, accompanied by male passenger) April 24, 2025 American Airlines Flight 950, SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil to New York City, USA Facts: A female passenger in first class attempted to storm the cockpit, reportedly upset over a flight delay. Crew members restrained her, knocking her to the floor, as seen in video footage. A male passenger also became disruptive, yelling in Portuguese at the crew. The incident occurred before takeoff, prompting the plane to return to the gate. Both passengers were removed by law enforcement. The flight, bound for John F. Kennedy International Airport, was delayed two hours and departed at 12:55 a.m. American Airlines stated that safety is their top priority and thanked customers for their understanding. No injuries were reported, and no further details on charges or passenger identities have been released.

content: To maximize your miles purchase during the Alaska Airlines buy miles bonus sale, follow these strategies: ### **1. Aim for the Highest Bonus Tier** - Purchase at least 30,000 miles in a single transaction to qualify for the maximum 60% bonus, which reduces the cost per mile to 1.97Â¢[1][4]. - Elite members can buy unlimited miles, so leverage this if you hold elite status[1][4]. ### **2. Plan for Specific Redemptions** - Use purchased miles for high-value redemptions, such as premium cabin flights. For example, a New York to London business class flight costs 45,000 miles, which could save you over $1,400 compared to cash fares[3]. - Alaska Airlines partners with top-tier airlines like Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific, and British Airways, offering excellent redemption opportunities[4]. ### **3. Split Transactions if Needed** - Non-elite members can purchase up to 150,000 miles annually but are limited to 100,000 miles per transaction. If you need more miles, split your purchases across multiple transactions[1][4]. ### **4. Use Marriott Bonvoy Points Strategically** - Transfer Marriott Bonvoy points to Alaska Mileage Plan at a 3:1 ratio with a 5,000-mile bonus for every 60,000 points transferred. This can lower your effective cost per mile to around 1.44Â¢[2]. ### **5. Avoid Speculative Buying** - Only purchase miles if you have specific travel plans in mind to avoid potential devaluations or unused balances[3]. ### **6. Consider Taxes and Fees** - Remember that miles are purchased through https://t.co/GnGoEVY2zM for $27.50 per 1,000 miles plus tax. Factor this into your cost calculations[1][4]. By combining these strategies and targeting high-value redemptions, you can extract maximum value from this promotion while minimizing costs.

content: Letâ€™s look at Freshpet $fprt which is now trading at $7.8 billion enterprise value, with close to $1 billion in revenues and has been growing 20% to 30% a year like clockwork. Why is this business valued at 8x revenues? Clearly the growth keeps coming and the failure of $pets or $bark not diversifying is how they got ahead. I do think a few things can or will happen. $frpt uses its stock currency to acquire companies in the space, why? Their gross margins are low and have never turned a profit. Their stock currency is their most valuable asset right now and if they ever want to be profitable they are going to need better margin businesses, sure growth may slow a bit but they will start to become profitable. Nevertheless, it proves my point that with $bark or any business that starts to grow the multiples expand the question what range? I tend to have a mental model matrix. Negative to flat growth. .25 to .5x revenues. Maybe lower if burning lots of cash or lots of debt. 5% rev growth is .5 to 1x revenue higher if there is operating income, lower if there is none. 10% is 1x revenue and if operating income is positive then 1.5 times revenue. 15 to 20% revenue growth rate is 1.5 to 3x revenue multiple and if profitable maybe more than 3x 30% or more is looking at 5x or more revenue multiples especially if profitable, now if the revenue growth is short term growth spurt then not but if there is large demand or large addressable market then it can keep going. I would rather have a 10% to 15% grower that is profitable than a 30% and unprofitable business, sure one can trade more, I get that but the other can be a 10 to 100 bagger and shows it has industry staying power or even pricing power to have a valid economy moat. Bark is going from the first level to the second level with a decent shot at the third and 4th but the 5th level is a 1% probability. This is how you catch these â€œturnaroundsâ€ or 10 to 100 baggers. Going from level 1 to 3. Level 1 to 5 is either fraudulent or monopoly dream, google, apple, etc. Think $bark given their exec team is going to tap into as much commerce as possible, they say they can get to 33% of revenues and now like 17% which is close to $75mm so a double would be $150mm plus assuming sub boxes grows 3% a year, looking at revenues of 575 to 600mm by calendar 2026, add in airline and new product categories and you have a growth stock again. QT @valuemaverick1: I was thinking of how $bark could get to $1 billion in revenues and the clearest path there seems to be the airline. Ran some math and believe there is a demand for hundreds of flights a week where the ARPF is 60k to 100k. Maybe I am wrong but here it goes. A 737 plane has around 32 rows of 6 seats each row, avg revenue per seat is $400, including first class. Or $76,000 a flight. In order to convert that for dogs, it would need to be 16 to 18 rows, and looking at 32 sections/seats of 1 to 2 owners and 1 dog. The price for 1 pet and 1 owner would go from their current 6,000 to 2,000, maybe can add another human for $1,000 since well couples fly with pets not just 1. So, 36 pet sections with 1 adult is $72,000 then the luggage is significantly less than a typical flight since instead of 192 people where they check in 1 bag at 40 pounds avg. or 4 tons of luggage the luggage will be significantly less, which means the luggage can be sold for cargo where they can monetize further the revenue per flight. So, assume you fly 4 times a week from NYC to Miami, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2 flights a day or 8 flights. 36 x 2000 is $72,000 per flight x 8 $576,000 x 52 is $30,000,000 I am not including the cargo as I donâ€™t know how much that would be but I assume it can be tens of thousands of dollars per flight. There is easily hundreds of these flights. LAX to nyc, sfo to nyc, sfo to Miami, sfo to lax, sfo to Lvs, etc etc. This can get this segment alone to produce a few hundred million in revenue per year, I assume the gross margin would be 10% but it would be straight to bottom line. Letâ€™s not get into loyalty miles programs etc, which is a license to print money as American Airlines has. Point is. No one is farting in this growth. Failing airlines provide massive opportunities for this to be possible. Good amount of capacity can be taken from current fleets, it all starts with 1 plane, a few routes and it will keep growing. I donâ€™t want to sound like some crazy bullish guy but it seems to all start going for them, $bark delivers on commerce and gets this going and we can see 10 to 20% consistent growth again and a rerating to 2x times revenue.

Pittsburghese, or Western Pennsylvania English, is a distinct American dialect centered in Pittsburgh, known for unique vocabulary (like "yinz" for you all, "buggy" for shopping cart, "jimmies" for sprinkles) and pronunciation influenced by Scots-Irish, German, Slavic, and other immigrant groups, creating a mix of unique phrases and an iconic, often nasal, accent with terms like "nebby" (nosy) and "needs fixed". Key Features â€¢Vocabulary: Words like "dahntahn" (downtown), "red up" (clean up), "clicker" (remote), and "slippy" (slippery) are common. â€¢Pronunciation: A unique nasal quality, particularly in vowels, with a distinctive "ah" sound, and mergers like "cot" and "caught". â€¢Grammar: Usage of "whenever" for specific times ("Whenever I get home...") and the "needs fixed" construction ("The car needs washed"). â€¢Influences: A blend of Scots-Irish, German, Slavic, African American, and even Old Norse, from waves of immigration. â€¢Identity: Strongly associated with the working-class community, with speakers called "Yinzers," and celebrated through local culture like t-shirts and media. Examples â€¢Yinz: "Yinz wanna go for a buggy ride?" (You all want to go for a shopping cart ride?). â€¢Red up: "I gotta red up the house." (I have to clean up the house). â€¢Jimmies: "Put some jimmies on that ice cream." (Put sprinkles on that ice cream). Origin and Spread Originating in the 18th century with Scots-Irish settlers, it absorbed influences from subsequent immigrant groups, solidifying into a unique dialect by the mid-20th century, with its distinctiveness becoming a point of local pride and study for linguists. Curt Cignetti was born June 2, 1961, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He is the son of Hall-of-Fame coach Frank Cignetti Sr. Cignetti played quarterback for the West Virginia Mountaineers from 1979 to 1982 under head coaches Frank Cignetti Sr. and Don Nehlen. Actor Jimmy Stewart is from Indiana, Pennsylvania. I never heard anyone I was related to use the words Jimmies or Buggies. James Stewart was often called Jimmy. Although I never met the man, I did see him board a flight from Los Angeles to New York on an American Airlines 747 I was loading bags on down below on the ramp. Dann hÃ¶ren sie einfach auf zu arbeiten oder verlassen das Land. Das tun jetzt schon Hunderttausende jedes Jahr. Bei den Schulden ist allmÃ¤hlich auch das Ende der Fahnenstange erreicht. Solange die Bundesrepublik ein wirtschaftlich prosperierendes Land war, konnte man die Finanzquellen an den KapitalmÃ¤rkten nahezu beliebig anzapfen. Doch jetzt hat das grÃ¼n-linke Milieu recht erfolgreich die Deindustrialisierung Deutschlands eingeleitet. PlÃ¶tzlich ist nicht mehr sicher, ob wir das Geld, das wir uns pumpen, auch wirklich werden zurÃ¼ckzahlen kÃ¶nnen. Und plÃ¶tzlich bekommt auch Deutschland nicht mehr so einfach Geld von Ã¼berall her wie frÃ¼her. Das war auch der Anfang vom Ende der DDR: eine Kombination aus politischem Druck von innen und finanziellem Druck von auÃŸen. Trotzdem gibt es immer noch sehr viele Menschen, die all das nicht wahrhaben wollen. Sie weigern sich, die deutlichen Zeichen zu sehen â€“ und wenn sie sie sehen, dann weigern sie sich, sie richtig zu deuten. Doch es ist, wie es ist. Die SED hat gewonnen. â€Die schÃ¶nste List des Teufels ist es, uns davon zu Ã¼berzeugen, dass es ihn nicht gibt.â€œ (Charles Baudelaire â€“ â€Der freigiebige Spielerâ€œ, 1864)

WÃ¤hrend sie anderen vorschreibt, dass Fliegen bÃ¶se ist, jettete sie selbst frÃ¶hlich durch die Weltgeschichte. Ihre Antwort? â€Ich hatte ja keine Wahl.â€œ Genau. Weil es ja auch keine ZÃ¼ge gibt. Oder Videokonferenzen. Oder einen Funken Konsequenz in ihren eigenen Forderungen. content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown alot this year, and while I don't enjoy the 16+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlinesThey

content: Air France has announced that starting in the summer of 2025, it will begin offering high-speed WiFi on select flights through a partnership with Starlink. This service will gradually be introduced across various routes, including regional ones, and will be complimentary for all passengers. The WiFi service aims to replicate the connectivity experience one would expect on the ground, allowing passengers to maintain communication, keep up with news, engage in online gaming, and stream media during their flight. The service will support multiple device connections per passenger, accessible via smartphones, tablets, and laptops. To use the WiFi, passengers will need to log in with their Flying Blue account, though first-class travelers can access it directly without login. For those without an account, one can be created at no cost after boarding. This initiative comes alongside Air France's recent decision to experiment with a paid Ã  la carte meal service on certain European routes, moving away from complimentary in-flight meals. The connectivity will be provided by Starlink's extensive network of low-earth orbit satellites, which ensures wide coverage, with the exception of areas where internet use is restricted. This follows similar moves by airlines like Hawaiian Airlines, which started its Starlink service in February 2024, and United Airlines, which has partnered with SpaceX for similar purposes.

content: What an awesome and uplifting story. God bless you both. https://t.co/edn8t6pKtv QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: Ever feel like your house is in a flight simulator? You're not alone. Letâ€™s talk airplane noise. Itâ€™s one of those things people either shrug off or passionately debate like pineapple on pizza or whether socks belong with sandals. But for some of us, itâ€™s not just a background hum... itâ€™s a full-blown soundtrack to our lives. Now, before anyone jumps in with â€œDidnâ€™t you know there was an airport when you bought your house?â€ Yes, I did. But hereâ€™s the thing: noise is a symptom, not the root cause. Itâ€™s like having a fever, it tells you somethingâ€™s up. And lately, something is up. My Noise vs. Your Noise I live in a low flyover zone about 3.5 miles from the airport. Iâ€™ve lived in three different homes in this area since 2014, and I swear the noise has changed, especially in the last two years. Itâ€™s not just louder; itâ€™s different. The recent United expansion got me curious, so I started digging into the data. Iâ€™ve compiled a report for September 2025 using info from the airportâ€™s own monitoring tools. This focuses on my area, using readings from monitors along the departure and arrival routes. If you live near Black Rail Road or Vista Fire Station #5, youâ€™d need to check your own local data to see how it compares. Tools You Can Use â€¢ Noise Dashboard: Created by the San Marcos PAAC rep (with help from the airport manager, I suspect), this dashboard is a goldmine for noise nerds like me. You can explore real data and trends here: ğŸ‘‰ Noise Dashboard: https://t.co/BnWHVAwT1Y â€¢ WebTrak: Want to know what just roared over your house? WebTrak lets you track flights and noise levels. Thereâ€™s a 15â€“30-minute delay, so jot down the time you heard it and use the replay feature. ğŸ‘‰ WebTrak: https://t.co/BVExdCFbNv Whatâ€™s That Sound? Letâ€™s break it down: â€¢ Small Prop Planes: These are the quiet buzzers. Unless theyâ€™re doing aerial acrobatics or having a bad day, theyâ€™re barely noticeable. Think of them as the Prius of the skies. â€¢ Turboprops: These guys sound like angry weed whackers. They can hit 70â€“75 dB, which is loud enough to pause a conversation or make your dog give you the side-eye. â€¢ Midsize Jets: Your typical business-class birds. They hum like a small industrial machine and get louder as they approach. Not ear-shattering, but definitely noticeable. â€¢ Big Jets (JSX, AA, etc.): These are the heavy hitters. JSX jets average around 75 dB over my neighborhood, and American Airlines jets can hit 80 dBâ€”comparable to a Harley or a loud air compressor. Not dangerous for your hearing in short bursts, but enough to spike your blood pressure or make you forget what you were saying. â€¢ Aggressive Maneuvers: My personal least favorite. These sudden, loud flyovers feel like the sky is yelling at you. Theyâ€™ve become more frequent, possibly due to air traffic control managing tighter flight paths. Iâ€™ve started documenting these in hopes someone can help figure out a solution. What the Data Says Iâ€™ve attached a summary of this monthâ€™s WebTrak report. Over the past three months, noise events have increased by 15% compared to last year, with September alone up 9% over September 2024. But hereâ€™s the kicker: complaints have skyrocketed, especially since the new monitor was installed near Loker Ave. Vista went from 4 to 197 complaints. San Marcos, despite being one of the most impacted areas, shows fewer complaints. Why? Maybe the complaint system doesnâ€™t recognize our addresses (Iâ€™ve tried!), or maybe weâ€™re a windows-shut, grin-and-bear-it kind of crowd. I live about 1,200 feet from the monitor and hear planes often. Most donâ€™t bother me, except those dive-bombers. Those are next-level annoying. Final Thought Noise isnâ€™t just about volume, itâ€™s about impact. If youâ€™ve noticed changes or have insights into the odd data trends, Iâ€™d love to hear from you. Letâ€™s keep the conversation going (when the jets arenâ€™t interrupting us).

content: @HustleBitch_ Iâ€™m not a fan of Junior or really any of the family. But (1) those are steps from the jet bridge down to the ramp used by multiple personnel (not private); (2) Lufthansa, Air France even Delta in a more limited manner will use individual cars (Porsches in LHâ€™s case) to bring international first class pax (or super elite freq fliers) from their lounges directly to the plane on the ramp and to those sorts of stairs.; (3) decades ago I saw Sean and Robin Wright Penn get the same treatment at JFK.; (4) the first family has Secret Service details that likely arrange these transfers and would seek to avoid the terminals if at all possible for security reasons; (5) better they are flying commercial (and a cheap one at that) than the expense/waste/environmental impact of private or government planes. Plenty to criticize the Trumps about. But this is weak stuff.

@elonmusk "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: I would panic myself to death in this situation. https://t.co/AFkGJLODDN QT @HansMokeNiemann: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed our version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.

content: @ERAUBusinessDB https://t.co/KvecviUUvh QT @archeohistories: In 1987, Steve Rothstein made a decision that seemed almost outrageous at the time: he paid \$250,000 for American Airlinesâ€™ unlimited â€œgolden ticket,â€ granting him free first-class flights for life. On top of that, he purchased a \$150,000 companion pass so he could bring anyone along. For Steve, travel wasnâ€™t about collecting miles or rewardsâ€”it was about freedom without limits, and he used it to the fullest. Over the years, Rothstein booked more than 10,000 flights, sometimes hopping on a plane just to have lunch in another state before returning home the same day. He was known for his generosity, often giving away trips to strangers, helping homeless individuals reunite with their families, or booking seats for companions who never showed up. His unusual habits made him both a legend and a financial headache, as American Airlines eventually calculated that he had cost them over \$21 million. In 2008, the airline revoked his pass, accusing him of misuse. But Rothstein fought back, pointing to the binding contract he had purchased decades earlier. The courts sided with him, and his golden ticket remained valid. Today, Steve Rothstein is remembered not only as the most extraordinary frequent flyer but also as a symbol of how one small clause in a contract can unlock the entire world. content: Flight attendant tapes phone to toilet seat to record young girls using bathroom. https://t.co/nuQvScKAtt QT @CollinRugg: NEW: American Airlines flight attended pleas guilty to recording underaged girls in airplane bathrooms. Estes Carter Thompson III was caught secretly filming a 14-year-old girl using the bathroom by taping his phone to the back of the toilet. Investigators were shocked to find that Thompson had videos of children (aged 7, 9, 11, & 14) from other flights. Thompson was finally caught after an incident in late 2023. He had noticed a girl was waiting for the bathroom and told her to come with him to the first-class bathroom. Before entering the lavatory, Thompson said he needed to wash his hands. When inside the bathroom, he taped his phone to the seat. The girl didn't notice the phone until she got up. She took a picture to show her mother. (seen below) The mother then told her father who confronted Thompson in the back of the plane where a "kerfuffle" went down, according to the family's lawyer. content: British Airways plans to introduce a new First Class on its double-decker Airbus SE A380s in mid-2026, betting that the most expensive seats at the front of the plane will still have space in the cabin even as business class bunks become more luxurious. The first class will feature a 79-inch (2-meter) long and 36.5-inch wide seat that reclines into a full-flat bed and features a cocoon divider. Other perks include a 32-inch TV screen, as well as a companion dining area and personal luggage storage.

content: @AmericanAir has demonstrated highly unsatisfactory customer service. My family of nine, who had pre-selected seats together for our international travel months in advance, found our seating arrangements changed, resulting in us being dispersed across the plane due to updates made by American Airlines. Upon contacting customer service to rectify this issue, I encountered two representatives who attempted to impose additional charges per ticket, despite the seats not being in first class. Furthermore, when I politely requested to escalate the matter to a higher supervisor, the call was abruptly disconnected. It is clear that American Airlines prioritizes profit over customer satisfaction, particularly when the airline itself was responsible for the disruption. I would advise against using @AmericanAir for your travel needs!

content: @OneMileataTime Transatlantic, we've only splurged eastbound overnight business class flights to sleep... but that never seems to work out because we want to enjoy the service (especially Air France). We're lucky if we can get 3 hours rest because of the short flight time, but it is comfy. TBH, KLM's new Premium Economy is an excellent substitute when their BC redemptions are too high and hope for a last minute upgrade opportunity on money or points. I find it harder to justify a daytime westbound in business class, even from a carriers hub. We'll fly economy, last row of preferred in an aisle/window hoping the middle stays open and order a premium meal (KLM FTW) and watch the same movies together.

content: @fretfretfret @HansMokeNiemann Ach, here's yer chess lad's travel tale in proper Scottish patter: Ah wanted tae spill the beans on whit a chess player's life's really like. Afore Wijk Aan Zee, ah thocht ah'd nip intae Vienna on the way, an' ah snagged a braw cheap business class ticket. Trip started aff smooth as, ah rocked up early tae the airport, but they wanted a printed boarding pass. Nae wifi, but a fan spotted me, so ah offered a photie if he'd share his hotspot. Sorted! Checked in, but they said equipment shortage meant a plane swap, bumpin' me doon tae economy. The auld yin had 14 fancy seats, new yin only 8, so six o' us drew the short straw. They were decent, blocked aff a hale row in economy, still a bit mingin' though. No' a nightmare yet, but jist the start. Landed in Abu Dhabi, lookin' forward tae a comfy seat tae Vienna. But the captain pipes up "10 minutes tae landin'", half an hour later, nae landin'. Weather's pure howlin', so we're circlin' like eejits. Efter an hour, plan wis Munich, but we end up in Frankfurt. They said same plane back tae Vienna at 8pm. Ah spied an 11:45 flight earlier, booked it tae save time. 'Course, it gets cancelled an hour afore, an' aw ither flights full. Lufthansa rebooks me tae Dusseldorf then Vienna. Efter 24 hours o' travel hell, cancellations, dosh doon the pan, ah take it an' arrive at 7pm. Ye might think this is pure doom an' gloom, but it's a grand sign for ma chess! Whenever these travel stooshies hit, especially in the pandemic, braw results followed. So aw ma bad luck's oot, an' things should gang ma way noo!

content: @toryboypierce @British_Airways Sadly itâ€™s not the Same anymore Andrew. Read my experience few days ago. I really donâ€™t wish anyone to go through this. It felt like flying with Ryanair with that kind of customer service. https://t.co/SCfM22y8bs QT @sash_jpg: A story about @British_Airways I had a flight booked for Thursday to see my dad, who was extremely unwell with Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Sadly, on Sunday, he passed away. I contacted British Airways customer service, and they told me not to worry they could move me to an earlier flight. The only option available connected via Nairobi. As it was a 26-hour journey, I asked to upgrade to the maximum possible. I was told there was no Business Class available, despite my return ticket being Business (Club World). The agent who helped rebook the flight reassured me and specifically said, â€œDonâ€™t worry, youâ€™ll be able to use our lounges during the connection.â€ When I arrived in Nairobi, no one could tell me which lounge I was allowed to use. The British Airways team said their lounge was only available if I was upgraded to Club World again. Their connecting flight partner said I couldnâ€™t use their lounge either. None of my cards Amex, Revolut Gold, or anything else worked. I messaged British Airways repeatedly, explaining that I was stuck in the airport, hadnâ€™t eaten for two days, and was travelling immediately after losing my father. I didnâ€™t asked for any other help, I just needed somewhere to rest. There was zero empathy and no effort to resolve the situation. Almost no concern at all. Even your cabin crew were shocked that no hotel, lounge access, or basic support had been arranged for me. So thank you, British Airways. You can call yourself whatever kind of airline you want but when I needed you the most, you didnâ€™t show up. In the end I upgraded my connection flight via their partner airline directly. The lesson here: donâ€™t waste your time on loyalty. It doesnâ€™t pay nor it comes when you need it the most. And drop those Amex gold bullshit, nothing helps when itâ€™s urgent urgent.

@LibertyCappy âœˆï¸In 1987, Steven Rothstein purchased an unlimited first-class ticket from American Airlines for $250,000, allowing him to fly anywhere for free. He frequently used the ticket, even for casual trips, and shared its benefits by booking companion tickets for others. âœˆï¸ In 2008, American Airlines revoked his pass, accusing him of fraudulent practices, such as booking seats under fictitious names to hold them. He sued for breach of contract, but in 2011, the U.S. District Court upheld the airline's decision. The case was eventually settled out of court in 2012 after delays caused by the airline's bankruptcy.

content: This is how American citizens are supposed to be. Helping each other out. https://t.co/PnKlKoKv5P QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: My appreciation for @Emirates is not only because they offer the best First Classâ€”they donâ€™t. The First Class cabins of Etihad, Singapore Airlines, and Air France are all more spacious than Emiratesâ€™. What truly sets Emirates apart is the consistency of its service and the global reach of its network. Once, after finishing a trip in a poor African country, the moment I stepped onto an Emirates aircraft and was welcomed with the familiar Arabic coffee and dates, I knew that even though I hadnâ€™t taken off yet, I was already home. No other airlines offer First Class services to these underdeveloped destinations.

content: Before the last elections in Nigeria, the Senator was on course to take up roles at the United Nations and this move was genuinely backed by both Oxford and Cambridge Universities, where he has both studied and lectured. I personally sat with him in his office at Cambridge University and asked why he was going to run for election in Nigeria. The plan was for him to be on this journey of academic pursuit and then contribute his intellect on a global scale. But, his core thesis for his PhD at Cambridge in which he interviewed a least 3 living presidents of Nigeria and several parastatals, provided great insights on failed mega projects in Nigeria. He explained in his thesis and the eventual book, that since 1960, Nigeria has had over 10,000 mega projects fail. This thesis I believe attracted the relevant personnel to convince him to return to Nigeria to run for the senate and work with Mr President to drive the mandate to redevelop Nigeria, at least in stirring the legislative strategy for both reform and visionary moves for the future. In rescent times, the image of Nigeria has been under fire, not just from internal insecurities and what I call â€œapoptosisâ€, it is now imperative that Nigeria have a serious academic, global diplomacy strategic mind at the global boardrooms to have a voice that shines the light of the country than we have ever done before. That role suits well for the man who has in the past 10 years invested heavily in understanding the world from the perspective of Harvard University, London School of Economics, Cambridge University and Oxford University. All of those universities alone have confidence in Dr Ibrahim's intellect and communication skills. In one journey, we flew a 6-hour flight on British Airways and forgo all our 1st class privileges like food and a nice bed to discuss his thesis and his passion to see Nigeria's mega projects come back to life or end. To be honest, I was upgraded Business Class to First, just to continue the lectures from his thesis. Kennedy International Airport (JFK). You won't want to spend 18 hours in an uncomfortable seat â€” so use your Membership Rewards to fly business class. content: The weird stories you find onlineğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ A British Airways flight attendant, Haden Pentecost, was found naked and under the influence of methamphetamine and amphetamines in an airplane bathroom during a flight from San Francisco to London in May 2025. Pentecost was a member of the cabin crew, not a passenger, and was on duty at the time of the incident. Details of the incident: â€¢Behavior: Colleagues described him as "dishevelled, pale, sweaty and erratic" before he locked himself in the business class lavatory. When he emerged, he was "completely naked and oblivious" to the fact, babbling incoherently. â€¢Response: A co-worker dressed him and moved him to an empty seat. The captain was alerted, and a medical professional on board was called to monitor him for the rest of the flight. â€¢Aftermath: Upon landing at Heathrow Airport, paramedics met the aircraft and took him to the hospital. Blood tests confirmed the presence of methamphetamine and amphetamines in his system. He was later dismissed by British Airways. â€¢Legal Outcome: Pentecost pleaded guilty to performing an aviation function while impaired by drugs. In September 2025, he received a six-month prison sentence, suspended for a year, along with 80 hours of unpaid work. The judge noted that no passengers were aware of his condition during the flight.

content: Letâ€™s look at Freshpet $fprt which is now trading at $7.8 billion enterprise value, with close to $1 billion in revenues and has been growing 20% to 30% a year like clockwork. Why is this business valued at 8x revenues? Clearly the growth keeps coming and the failure of $pets or $bark not diversifying is how they got ahead. I do think a few things can or will happen. $frpt uses its stock currency to acquire companies in the space, why? Their gross margins are low and have never turned a profit. Their stock currency is their most valuable asset right now and if they ever want to be profitable they are going to need better margin businesses, sure growth may slow a bit but they will start to become profitable. Nevertheless, it proves my point that with $bark or any business that starts to grow the multiples expand the question what range? I tend to have a mental model matrix. Negative to flat growth. .25 to .5x revenues. Maybe lower if burning lots of cash or lots of debt. 5% rev growth is .5 to 1x revenue higher if there is operating income, lower if there is none. 10% is 1x revenue and if operating income is positive then 1.5 times revenue. 15 to 20% revenue growth rate is 1.5 to 3x revenue multiple and if profitable maybe more than 3x 30% or more is looking at 5x or more revenue multiples especially if profitable, now if the revenue growth is short term growth spurt then not but if there is large demand or large addressable market then it can keep going. I would rather have a 10% to 15% grower that is profitable than a 30% and unprofitable business, sure one can trade more, I get that but the other can be a 10 to 100 bagger and shows it has industry staying power or even pricing power to have a valid economy moat. Bark is going from the first level to the second level with a decent shot at the third and 4th but the 5th level is a 1% probability. This is how you catch these â€œturnaroundsâ€ or 10 to 100 baggers. Going from level 1 to 3. Level 1 to 5 is either fraudulent or monopoly dream, google, apple, etc. Think $bark given their exec team is going to tap into as much commerce as possible, they say they can get to 33% of revenues and now like 17% which is close to $75mm so a double would be $150mm plus assuming sub boxes grows 3% a year, looking at revenues of 575 to 600mm by calendar 2026, add in airline and new product categories and you have a growth stock again. Then I believe they will go into other verticals perhaps freshfod or extent their pet toys brands by acquiring Amazon companies. QT @valuemaverick1: I was thinking of how $bark could get to $1 billion in revenues and the clearest path there seems to be the airline. Ran some math and believe there is a demand for hundreds of flights a week where the ARPF is 60k to 100k. Maybe I am wrong but here it goes. A 737 plane has around 32 rows of 6 seats each row, avg revenue per seat is $400, including first class. Or $76,000 a flight. In order to convert that for dogs, it would need to be 16 to 18 rows, and looking at 32 sections/seats of 1 to 2 owners and 1 dog. The price for 1 pet and 1 owner would go from their current 6,000 to 2,000, maybe can add another human for $1,000 since well couples fly with pets not just 1. So, 36 pet sections with 1 adult is $72,000 then the luggage is significantly less than a typical flight since instead of 192 people where they check in 1 bag at 40 pounds avg. or 4 tons of luggage the luggage will be significantly less, which means the luggage can be sold for cargo where they can monetize further the revenue per flight. So, assume you fly 4 times a week from NYC to Miami, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2 flights a day or 8 flights. 36 x 2000 is $72,000 per flight x 8 $576,000 x 52 is $30,000,000 I am not including the cargo as I donâ€™t know how much that would be but I assume it can be tens of thousands of dollars per flight. There is easily hundreds of these flights. LAX to nyc, sfo to nyc, sfo to Miami, sfo to lax, sfo to Lvs, etc etc. This can get this segment alone to produce a few hundred million in revenue per year, I assume the gross margin would be 10% but it would be straight to bottom line. Letâ€™s not get into loyalty miles programs etc, which is a license to print money as American Airlines has. Point is. No one is farting in this growth. Failing airlines provide massive opportunities for this to be possible. Good amount of capacity can be taken from current fleets, it all starts with 1 plane, a few routes and it will keep growing. I donâ€™t want to sound like some crazy bullish guy but it seems to all start going for them, $bark delivers on commerce and gets this going and we can see 10 to 20% consistent growth again and a rerating to 2x times revenue.

They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. content: Regina and the Gravy Train That Never Stops at Connolly Station Hello @ReginaDo !! Picture the scene: Regina Doherty, Fine Gaelâ€™s answer to a Ryanair boarding pass (overpriced, slightly crumpled, and always trying to sell you something extra), logs onto X with the solemnity of a woman whoâ€™s just discovered a new filter that hides the Brussels tan. She fires off a post tut-tut tweet about Elon Musk @elonmusk daring to mention Irish sovereignty, as if the very word â€œsovereigntyâ€ is a dangerous foreign import, like garlic or womenâ€™s rights. Within minutes the replies come thundering in. Not a gentle Connemara drizzle of disagreement, mind, but a biblical deluge of â€œRegina, love, youâ€™ve been in Brussels longer than the Berlaymont buildingâ€™s carpet. When exactly did you last buy a pint in Fingal without an expense claim?â€ Ninety percent of the responses (yes, ninety) are essentially variations on â€œCop on to yourself.â€ The other ten percent are bots, and even they seem embarrassed. But Regina is unflappable. She has the serene confidence of a woman who knows the gravy train doesnâ€™t just have first-class carriages; it has an entire spa car where Irish MEPs go to have their principles exfoliated. â€œAh here,â€ tweets a lad from Tallaght, â€œthe actual Tallaght, not the one in her imagination where everyone wants a directly elected mayor of Brussels. â€œYouâ€™re more offended by Elon saying â€˜sovereigntyâ€™ than you were by the fact we canâ€™t build houses because half the planning laws are now written in Belgian.â€ Another chips in: â€œRegina, the only border youâ€™re interested in is the one between economy and business class on the Dublinâ€“Strasbourg flight.â€ She tries the classic politician pivot: â€œIâ€™m proud to represent the Irish people in Europe.â€ The people reply: â€œGrand. Whenâ€™s the next flight home, then? Weâ€™ve a few questions about water charges, housing, and why every second press release from you sounds like it was translated from Dutch by Google.â€ At this point Reginaâ€™s media advisor (a man who has the haunted eyes of someone who once saw MicheÃ¡l Martin eat a salad) whispers, â€œMaybe dial back the â€˜Elon badâ€™ stuff, Senator. The comment section looks like the Rose of Tralee if the roses were on fire.â€ But Regina is committed now. Sheâ€™s all-in, like a poker player whoâ€™s mistaken a pair of twos for a full house because both cards have the EU flag on the back. You can almost hear the clatter of the gravy train from here: the golden cutlery, the endless canapÃ©s, the gentle hum of lobbyists murmuring, â€œDonâ€™t worry, Regina, the Irish people will forget in a week. They always do. Sure arenâ€™t they grand altogether?â€ Meanwhile, back in the real Ireland (the one that isnâ€™t airbrushed by a â‚¬7,000 monthly communications allowance), the replies keep coming. Farmers, nurses, young people whoâ€™ve never seen the inside of a house they can afford; all politely informing Madam Senator that her moral compass seems to have been replaced with a Brussels tram ticket. And itâ€™s only valid in one direction. The best reply of the night comes from a woman in Donegal: â€œRegina, pet, the only sovereignty movement youâ€™re part of is the one that moved your loyalty from Dublin to Strasbourg. Enjoy the waffles.â€ And somewhere, in a glass office overlooking a city that isnâ€™t Dublin, Regina Doherty stares at the screen, sips a taxpayer-funded herbal tea, and wonders why the Irish people are suddenly so ungrateful. After all, sheâ€™s only doing what every career politician dreams of: selling out so smoothly that even the buyers feel a little bit Irish. Choo-choo, Regina. Mind the doors. They only open outwards. @EireDonGaeilge QT @ReginaDo: Elon Musk wants the EU abolished. Medvedev applauds. That alone tells you who benefits from a weaker Europe. Stronger together never more so than now. https://t.co/2rhOPRx7Du

content: In 1987, Steve Rothstein purchased a $250,000 AAirpass from American Airlines, allowing unlimited first class travel. He took over 10,000 flights, costing the airline $21 million. The pass was terminated in 2008 due to alleged misuse. Rothstein was a Chicago entrepreneur, made an audacious purchase. For $250,000, he bought American Airlinesâ€™ AAirpass, a lifetime ticket that allowed unlimited first class travel with no blackout dates. At the time, the airline viewed the program as a clever way to generate quick cash from wealthy customers who were unlikely to fly constantly. That assumption turned out to be spectacularly wrong. Over the next twenty one years, Rothstein practically lived on airplanes. He booked and flew more than 10,000 flights, sometimes hopping between cities multiple times a day. Because the pass guaranteed first class seats, he routinely flew on some of the most expensive routes in the network without paying another cent. Internal estimates later suggested his flying cost American Airlines roughly $21 million in lost revenue. By 2008, American Airlines had had enough. The company terminated Rothsteinâ€™s pass, accusing him of violating the agreement by booking speculative flights he did not intend to take and misusing companion privileges. Rothstein publicly denied wrongdoing and disputed the airlineâ€™s interpretation of the contract. Despite the controversy, there was no dramatic courtroom resolution. The pass was never reinstated, and no detailed settlement or ruling was made public. The dispute simply faded, with the airline keeping its decision intact. The fallout permanently reshaped airline thinking. American had already stopped selling AAirpasses in the early 1990s, but Rothsteinâ€™s case became the definitive cautionary tale inside the industry. What seemed like a harmless lifetime perk in the 1980s proved financially dangerous once airlines gained better data on customer behavior. Only a few dozen AAirpasses were ever sold, and none remain valid today... Â© Reddit #archaeohistories

content: When One Seat Goes Viral, It Exposes an Industry Problemâ€ A short video showing generous legroom on a WestJet flight out of Edmonton went viral for a simple reason: people were shocked that economy class could still look humane. That reaction says more about todayâ€™s airline industry than about one airplane seat. Passengers have been conditioned to expect shrinking legroom, extra fees for basic comfort, and cabins designed more for revenue optimization than human dignity. So when a single seat offers space to breathe, stretch, and exist without apology, it feels like an exceptionâ€”almost a miracle. This was likely an exit row or a specific aircraft configuration, not a system-wide policy change. But thatâ€™s precisely the point. Comfort has been elevated to a privilege, rather than a standard. Airlines sell â€œextraâ€ legroom as if dignity were a luxury add-on rather than a baseline expectation. The viral video didnâ€™t celebrate WestJet. It exposed how low the bar has fallen. When basic comfort becomes newsworthy, the industry should ask itself a hard question: When did treating passengers like cargo become normal? Because people arenâ€™t asking for first class. Theyâ€™re asking for space to sitâ€”without viral proof that itâ€™s even possible. #CPRMRadio #EditorialCartoon #SymbolicArt #AirlineIndustry #PassengerRights #TravelReality #EconomyClass #Legroom #ComfortVsProfit #HumanDignity #ModernTravel #WhatWentWrong

content: In 1987, Rothstein purchased the â€˜AAirpassâ€™ from American Airlines for $250,000 which allowed him to fly first class for life at no additional cost. He flew thousands of times over the years and gifted a number of tickets to people as well. American Airlines cancelled his pass in 2008 because they claimed he booked excessive flights and misused the system. Although he sought legal action, his pass was never renewed. Rothsteinâ€™s situation is what encouraged American Airlines to abolish their unlimited pass program. #americanairlines #airoplane
