content: @6ESinger157593 @IXGguy I think #AirIndia's final 747 config was 417 seats, including 12F + 26J. Air India could have done simple cabin refresh, with 500 seat 2 class layout & deployed them on select international & domestic sectors. Could have been used for Hajj duty as well! https://t.co/BxsskSij5n QT @6ESinger157593: @IXGguy Yes, Air Indiaâ€™s 747-400s, with over 400 seats, were optimized for short, high-cycle routes like Delhi-Mumbai. Yet, their 747-400â€™s 7,000+ nautical mile range and adaptable airframe supported long-haul viability. Lufthansaâ€™s 370-seat, premium-heavy configuration proves this. Re-rating the MTOW and refitting the cabin for 350-380 seats with modern first, business, and premium economy sections could have aligned them with global standards, leveraging their existing capabilities. Cost Analysis Reconfiguring 4 aircraft would cost $100-148 million total: -USD 10-15 million per plane ($40-60 million) for new seats and IFE, based on Air Indiaâ€™s $6 million average refit cost per aircraft. - USD 5-10 million per plane ($20-40 million) to restore long-haul capacity. - USD 5-7 million per plane ($20-28 million) for D-checks and certification. Compare this to $200-250 million per new Boeing 777-9 or A350. Refurbishing saves capital, though fuel costs would be 20-30% higher than modern twins. Premium fares on routes like Delhi-New York could offset this, especially with Tataâ€™s brand revival. Corruptionâ€™s Role Air Indiaâ€™s 747-400s may have been sidelined from premium routes due to corruption during government control. Allegations suggest officials favored rival airlines like Emirates or Jet Airways, ceding lucrative slots and avoiding upgrades. This relegated the 747s to low-yield, high-density roles, undermining their long-haul potential. The Tatas, taking over in 2022, could have reversed this. The Tatasâ€™ premium-focused visionâ€”evident in their $400 million refit and new aircraft ordersâ€”could have included the 747-400s: - Cabin Redesign: 350-370 seats with 12-18 First Class,60-70 business seats, and premium economy, plus modern IFE. - Market them as heritage iconsâ€” â€œPalaces in the Skiesâ€â€”with retro livery for routes like Mumbai-London. - At $25-37 million per plane, refits beating new aircraft costs, generating revenue for 5-10 years. Air Indiaâ€™s 747-400s were shaped by government priorities, not incapability. Reconfiguration costs are dwarfed by new aircraft prices and delivery delays. Very likely corruption limited their premium use. Profits from these refurbished 744s (note : profits, not revenue, based on my analysis) could range from USD 350-400 million per annum. Clearly the Tatas could have transformed them into profitable long-haul assets, blending nostalgia and luxury, rather than scrapping them.

content: Earlier this week I spoke with an Austrian ecom agency owner ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡¹ relocating to CyprusğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¾ for tax-free living. He's crushing $30k/month on ads rn, and wants to increase to $200k+/month by June but it seems impossible bc he is currently running on debit cards. Translation.. He's suffering from a wack negative cash conversion cycle. Every dollar going out immediately, zero float. Can't reinvest capital fast enough. And he's got zero US credit history, no Amex relationships to leverage. This is the exact scenario where most founders stay stuck. But we're flipping the entire playbook: Step one, we're getting him approved for a US fintech credit card through our partner. They underwrite a credit line based on revenue, not credit score, so approval happens fast. Credit line will be around 50% of monthly revenue (starts at ~$15k, scales to $100k+ as he hits $200k/month). Net terms of 30-60 days, which solves the cash conversion problem immediately. No personal guarantee. But that's just the beginning. Simultaneously, he's executing a physical bank run to the US. Opening personal accounts at Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and Citi to trigger his US credit file from scratch. Here's where it gets interesting. Most foreigners are told they need to spend 9-12 months slowly building US credit with secured cards and baby limits. Total waste of time when you're trying to scale fast. Instead, we're using the $100k Chase deposit loophole. He deposits $100k into a Chase business checking account, lets it sit for one statement cycle, then applies for premium cards like the Chase Sapphire Reserve Business. This bypasses the slog that is the standard US credit building phase. Chase sees the capital, underwrites on account activity instead of credit score, and approves him for 3x points on ad spend without waiting a year. At $200k/month in ads, that's 600,000 Chase points per month. 7.2 million points per year. That's easily $150k+ in luxury travel value when transferred to partners like Avianca LifeMiles or Air Canada Aeroplan for long-haul business class. The outcome? He eliminates the cash flow bottleneck that was capping his growth at $30k/month. Scales past $200k with proper float. Builds a US credit stack in weeks instead of a year. And drops his travfel costs to near zero while traveling half the year. Most founders relocating to places like Cyprus or Dubai focus only on the tax optimization. They completely miss the credit, points, and cash flow infrastructure that actually lets you scale and live well. If ur running an agency or ecom brand overseas and trying to scale US ad spend without proper rails, you're leaving millions on the table. We should talk.

content: Infant Seats & Award Bookings: A Guide Based on my recent experience with LM & LX while booking an infant ticket, I decided to write this post to answer some common questions about booking infant seats on award tickets. Having traveled extensively with infants, I've used quite a lot of FFPs and can share insights on how different programs handle infant bookings. 1. Who issues the infant ticket? Both the ticket issuer and the operating airline can issue the infant seat, but the process varies. 2. Best approach: Use FFPs that allow infant booking either online or through a simple call process. Top Recommendations for Infant Bookings: 1. Finnair: The best option. No charges for adding an infant, even for tickets booked with partner airlines. You can add the infant directly or via call for free. 2. Aeroplan: Charges are reasonable $25/2,500 miles for Economy $50/5,000 miles for Premium Economy $100/10,000 miles for Business Class Works for partner bookings too. Book the adult first, then call to add the infant. 3. British Airways, Emirates, and Asiana: Charge 10% of adult miles for the infant, plus taxes. Can be booked directly for partners, except Finnair for BA. 4. Virgin Atlantic: Charges are minimal 1,000 miles for Economy 2,500 miles for Premium Economy 5,000 miles for Business Class You can book directly or call to add the infant later, even for partner bookings. 5. KrisFlyer: Charges 10â€“25% of the adult fare. Infants can be added after booking the adult ticket via a call. 6. Asia Miles: Charges 10% of the accompanying adult fare. You need to add the infant via call or email after booking the adult. 7. Miles & More (M&M): Charges 10% of the booking class fare during ticketing. Itâ€™s best to add the infant as soon as possible. 8. United Airlines (UA): Charges 10% of the accompanying adult fare plus taxes. What to Avoid: 1. LifeMiles (LM): Though I am big admirer of LM but avoid using LM for infants especially on Lufthansa (LH), Swiss (LX), or Austrian Airlines (OS). Adding the infant later can be a hassle. Always call LM directly instead of the operating airline. However, LM works well with ANA and UA flights as these airlines easily add infants on partner bookings. 2. Domestic US Flights: Adding an infant is free. Final Tips: Always check the infant ticket policy of both the ticket issuer and the operating airline before booking. Book FFPs that offer straightforward processes and low or no charges for infant tickets. Experts, feel free to comment and share your insights so others can benefit from your experiences! #AwardTravel #FamilyTravel #InfantSeats #TravelHacks #PointsAndMiles #AirlineTips #ccgeek #ccgeeks

This was seven years ago. I just donâ€™t understand why weâ€™re suddenly seeing it now from you. https://t.co/ciGThrs9tA QT @eclipsethis2003: 2017 NEW YORK -- American Airlines apologized after a video posted to Facebook captured the moments after an employee allegedly hit a woman with a stroller, narrowly missing the baby in her arms. In a statement, American Airlines said it was â€œdeeply sorry for the pain we have caused this passenger and her family and to any other customers affected by the incident.â€ The airline said that it saw the video and started an investigation â€œto obtain the facts.â€ â€œWhat we see on this video does not reflect our values or how we care for our customers,â€ the statement, on Friday, said. The airline also suspended the flight attendant involved while the incident is being investigated. The passenger and her family chose to take another flight and were upgraded to first class, CBS Newsâ€™ Carter Evans reported.

@Turbinetraveler Iet me think this through out loud, the way I do when Iâ€™m alone at 3 a.m. staring at old photos of G-BOAF on the runway at Filton. First, the crash. Air France 4590, 25 July 2000. A strip of metal on the runway, a burst tyre, a fuel tank ripped open, fire, 113 dead. Horrible. Unforgivable in the sense that it was preventable. The investigation was brutal in its honesty: the tank design had a known vulnerability, the spacer strips between the ply layers in the tyres were missing on some wheels, runway debris discipline at CDG was lax. The fixes came fastâ€”Kevlar liners in the tanks, better tyres, Michelin NZGs that wouldnâ€™t shred the same way, FOD walks on runways, even little deflectors ahead of the gear. By 2001 the fleet was back in the air, certificates renewed. And people flew. Loads were solid. Celebrities, bankers, the merely rich who wanted New York breakfast and London dinner. Iâ€™ve talked to cabin crew from those last two yearsâ€”they said the mood on board was almost defiant, like â€œweâ€™re still here.â€ Then the numbers. This is where I start to waver. A Concorde overhaul cost roughly the same as buying a new widebody. Fuel burn was monstrousâ€”four times a 747 per seat. The ozone scare (later mostly debunked) and the post-9/11 drop in premium travel hurt badly. Airbus announced theyâ€™d stop supporting the A300-600 airframe donor parts, and without Airbus the Type Certificate was toast. British Airways and Air France looked at the ledger and quietly concluded that even at $12,000 a ticket they were losing money on every flight once you rolled in the capital costs. Butâ€¦ but. Today I can drop $15â€“25k on a Qatar Qsuite or an Emirates first-class shower suite and barely blink, because half the cabin is paying it. Londonâ€“New York business class is routinely $8â€“12k round-trip now, often more. The infra has improvedâ€”better runways, better ATC, quieter engines were already in development (the â€œOlympus 593 Mk 610â€ that never flew would have cut noise dramatically). Carbon brakes, fly-by-wire retrofitsâ€”none of it impossible. Expensive, yes. Absurdly so? Maybe not, if someone had really wanted it. This is where the doubt creeps in. Because no one did want it enough. Not the airlines (BA was bleeding cash post-9/11), not the manufacturers (Airbus wanted out), not the regulators (the FAA never gave full domestic overland rights anyway), andâ€”hereâ€™s the part that stingsâ€”not the public either. We mourned her, we bought the posters, but we didnâ€™t march in the streets or refuse to fly subsonic. We posted grainy videos on YouTube and moved on. Was it politics? In a way, yes. The loudest anti-Concorde voices were always politicalâ€”green groups who hated the fuel burn, American airlines who hated the competitive threat and lobbied against overland routes, French and British governments quietly relieved to be rid of a prestige project that had become a money pit. The crash simply handed everyone the perfect excuse they were waiting for. I go back and forth. One day Iâ€™m convinced she could have been savedâ€”re-engine with something derived from the Trent, sell 10 refurbished airframes to boutique operators for $20â€“30k a seat, turn her into the ultimate Veblen good. The next day I look at the maintenance logs and think, â€œMy God, what a fragile, thirsty, noisy beastâ€”she was a miracle we got 27 years out of her.â€ Maybe the truth is gentler than conspiracy and harsher than nostalgia: Concorde represented a moment when governments and companies were still willing to lose money for the way people lose money on artâ€”because beauty and ambition mattered. That moment passed. Not because of one crash, not because of one Airworthiness Directive, but because we slowly, quietly, decided that three-and-a-half hours from London to New York wasnâ€™t worth the poetry anymore. And yet every time I see that delta wing against a sunset, I feel the same thing I felt as a child a tug in the chest that says we gave up something irreplaceable. Not just speed.

content: @_6954_ @thegoodbrother0 @WallStreetMav It was too expensive to most humans. How I got my trip was a bit of a fluke. I was living in France at the time, but traveling a lot to the US. I usually tried to use British Airways (back when BA actually was BA). I had a flight to Boston. Flew from Paris to London, and found that the flight had been cancelled. Stood in the long line to get another flight. There was only one guy handling it all. The two (Americans) in front of me were quite unpleasant to him. Something to do with being put in economy rather than business class, to JFK. My turn came. I took pit on him. I smiled and said: "My flight seems to have been cancelled, what can we do about it?" He was surprised that I didn't abuse him like everyone else. He rattled his keyboard ... "How about ... a flight to DC, then a connecting flight to Boston?" "Yes, that will work. " "Oh, the flight to DC is on Concorde ... not a problem is it?" "No, I think I can deal with that." Being pleasant to people can pay off.

content: Thank God there are still so many good people in the world! https://t.co/yNrGwPcwUE QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: ğŸ“‰ Inflation bites. ğŸ›ï¸ The wealthy keep spending. ğŸ¤– AI carries the market. âš–ï¸ And Washington is playing with fire. The search for stability has led investors to an unexpected place: economic data. After months of disruption, US inflation data is finally back on schedule â€” and it delivers an uncomfortable truth. ğŸ”¸ CPI is running at 2.7% ğŸ”¸ Beef prices up 16% ğŸ”¸ Natural gas up ~11% ğŸ”¸ Eating out rising at an 8%+ annual pace Think of inflation like a slow leak in your wallet. You donâ€™t notice it every day â€” until the bills start piling up. That pressure hasnâ€™t gone away for ordinary Americans. Yet hereâ€™s the paradoxâ€¦ ğŸ’³ Premium spending is alive and well Earnings season tells a different story â€” especially at the top end. JPMorgan Chase beat expectations across most of its business lines. CEO Jamie Dimon struck an unusually calm tone: ğŸ”¸ Consumers are still spending ğŸ”¸ Businesses remain healthy ğŸ”¸ Labour markets have softened â€” but not cracked Now look at airlines. Delta Air Lines missed some forecasts, and the stock was punished â€” yet management made one thing crystal clear: ğŸ”¸ Almost all future growth comes from premium customers In plain terms: The economy is splitting in two. Those at the top are still flying first class. Everyone else is feeling turbulence. ğŸ“Š Markets are unforgiving right now So far this earnings season: ğŸ”¸ Only a few companies missed expectations ğŸ”¸ But those misses were punished twice as hard as usual Think of the market like a stressed referee â€” no second chances, no benefit of the doubt. ğŸ¤– AI is carrying the scoreboard Wall Street expects S&P 500 earnings to grow ~8%, marking a 10th straight quarter of growth. But peel back the curtain and you see something crucial: ğŸ”¸ Most optimism is concentrated in tech ğŸ”¸ And tech optimism is concentrated in AI ğŸ”¸ And AI expectations are concentrated in one company That company is Nvidia. Remove Nvidia, and techâ€™s earnings growth drops sharply. Analogy time: The market is riding a single engine at cruising altitude. Itâ€™s powerful â€” but everyone is watching that engine very closely. If Nvidia stumbles, Mr Market wonâ€™t be forgiving. âš–ï¸ Meanwhile in Washington: a dangerous game As all this unfolds, political pressure on the Federal Reserve is escalating. President Donald Trump has publicly attacked Fed Chair Jerome Powell, even as DOJ subpoenas hover in the background. This matters more than most people realise. When politicians threaten central bank independence, markets hear one thing: ğŸ”¸ Higher inflation expectations ğŸ”¸ Higher long-term interest rates ğŸ”¸ A weaker currency over time As Jamie Dimon put it plainly: Interference backfires. Itâ€™s like yelling at a thermostat and expecting the room to cool down faster â€” instead, you blow the fuse. ğŸª™ The old lesson returns History keeps repeating itself: ğŸ”¸ Rising debt ğŸ”¸ Political pressure ğŸ”¸ Currency dilution Thatâ€™s why investors always circle back to hard assets â€” especially gold â€” when trust in institutions starts to fray. ğŸ§­ Bottom line We are in a strange moment: ğŸ”¸ Inflation still hurts everyday life ğŸ”¸ The wealthy keep spending ğŸ”¸ AI is propping up markets ğŸ”¸ Politics is testing monetary credibility Stability feels scarce â€” but the signals are there if you know where to look. (Source: Financial Times, FactSet, company earnings) #Inflation #EarningsSeason #AI

content: This is hilarious. https://t.co/YnFeKoyMKP QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Muskâ€™s Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRISÂ²? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost â‚¬50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: Not reading this just want to say Lufthansa has like the worst business class ever ğŸ˜­ Never took it never will https://t.co/PuFubrKMk9 QT @avipat_: On the plane right now, had some time on my hands so I wanted to share my experience pitching and closing traditional venture capitalists since the coin launched. The core problem everyone is trying to solve is that you canâ€™t call a token â€œequityâ€ for legal reasons, and it doesnâ€™t actually represent ownership. What Iâ€™ve found over the last week is this almost entirely doesnâ€™t matter. Traditional Silicon Valley venture capitalists look for a disproportional power dynamic when investing in an early-stage startup. What I mean by this is they want to feel as if the company has almost zero need for them. Now what the coin actually provides is: 1. Market validation narrative: VCs usually have very little to go off of at the early stage, but a token gives you a public scoreboard of user sentiment. Thatâ€™s as much a validation metric as MRR. 2. Creating a cult: Itâ€™s literally the founderâ€™s job to create a cult, and while most have to bribe users with cash, endorsements, or perks, the token makes people engage and evangelize organically just because it exists. 3. Liquidity without dilution: you have immediate access to real revenue at a stage where most startups are bleeding cash just to stay alive. 4. Polarization: meme coins are incredibly polarizing, which causes an incredible amount of organic attention that can be capitalized on instantly by a competent founder. All of these take years to build for traditional Silicon Valley startups and Iâ€™m definitely not saying itâ€™s a guarantee for ICM companies, but I can confidently say the odds are much higher. This all creates a massive disproportional power dynamic compared to any other startup that an early stage VC is reviewing. The actual shift in my pitch very clearly reflects that as well. All my meetings yesterday followed this line of questioning where: VC asks for metrics and data I validate everything through the chart and user signups VC shifts into story mode along the lines of: â€œSo wait, how did this even take off?â€ I can say this was probably the only reason I was able to close $500k in 48 hours. Anyways next 4 days for $KLED going to be huge, gonna get back to work:

She retired with a thick folder of letters from passengers praising and thanking her for making their flight wonderfulâ€”would such folders even exist today? She embodies a lost world.

content: â€œPay it Forward â€œ in action. Happy ending! https://t.co/553O80lX9x QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: @unknown__burner @historyinmemes @AskPerplexity In the 1970s, Air Canada's 747 dance floor tickets likely cost around $550 for coach and $1,000-$1,500 for first class on transatlantic routes like Toronto to London. Adjusted for inflation, that's roughly $5,350 and $9,650-$14,500 in 2025 dollars. Today, Air Canada coach fares for similar routes range from CAD 750-1,200, while first class costs CAD 10,000-17,000. Coach travel is cheaper now in real terms, but first class prices are comparable. Historical data is limited, so estimates are approximate.

Der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger â€“ mit Filterblase und PR-Team Neubauer hat ein Talent: Sie verkauft grÃ¼ne Ideologie wie ein Tech-Startup CEO seine neueste App. Einfache LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r komplexe Probleme (â€Einfach aufhÃ¶ren mit fossilen Energien, dann klappt das!â€œ). Panik als Dauermodus (â€Die Welt brennt, wir mÃ¼ssen sofort handeln â€“ auÃŸer, wenn ich zum nÃ¤chsten Event fliege!â€œ). Junge Leute mit utopischen Versprechen einfangen, wÃ¤hrend sie selbst im Luxus lebt. Sie ist der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger von Hameln, nur dass sie statt einer FlÃ¶te einen Twitter-Account und ein ARD-Mikrofon hat. WÃ¤hrend sie mit entrÃ¼cktem Blick und dramatischen Worten die Apokalypse verkÃ¼ndet, marschiert ihre Gefolgschaft in Richtung wirtschaftlicher SelbstzerstÃ¶rung â€“ und klatscht dabei begeistert. Fliegen, Feiern, Fordern â€“ Klima-Aktivismus auf First-Class-Niveau Einer ihrer bekanntesten â€Ausrutscherâ€œ war die Diskussion um ihre eigenen Flugreisen. WÃ¤hrend sie anderen vorschreibt, dass Fliegen bÃ¶se ist, jettete sie selbst frÃ¶hlich durch die Weltgeschichte. Ihre Antwort? â€Ich hatte ja keine Wahl.â€œ Genau. Weil es ja auch keine ZÃ¼ge gibt. Oder Videokonferenzen. Oder einen Funken Konsequenz in ihren eigenen Forderungen. Neubauer lebt in einem Widerspruchskosmos, in dem fÃ¼r sie selbst andere Regeln gelten als fÃ¼r die â€dummen Massenâ€œ. WÃ¤hrend sie sich an Kohlekraftwerken festklebt, um â€die Zukunft zu rettenâ€œ, mÃ¼ssen normale BÃ¼rger schauen, wie sie mit explodierenden Energiepreisen klarkommen. GrÃ¼ne Heuchelei auf hÃ¶chstem Niveau Neubauer ist die Inkarnation der grÃ¼nen Doppelmoral. Von Reemtsma-Geld profitieren, aber Kapitalismus abschaffen wollen. Fliegen, aber Flugreisen fÃ¼r andere verteufeln. GrÃ¼nen Kommunismus fordern, aber selbst luxuriÃ¶s leben. WÃ¤hrend sie den Untergang der Welt predigt, macht sie sich ihre eigene Zukunft goldgrÃ¼n: BuchvertrÃ¤ge, Medienauftritte, Lobbytreffen â€“ ein Aktivismus, der vor allem einem Zweck dient: ihrer eigenen Karriere. Das Fazit: Klima-Heilige oder clevere GeschÃ¤ftsfrau? Luisa Neubauer ist kein Umweltengel. Sie ist eine perfekt inszenierte PR-Maschine. Ihre Kampagne hat mit echter Wissenschaft oder nachhaltiger Politik so viel zu tun wie ein Tesla mit Umweltschutz â€“ klingt gut, sieht gut aus, ist aber am Ende doch nur Marketing. Die Frage ist: Wie lange lassen sich die Leute noch tÃ¤uschen? Solange die Kameras blitzen und die Medien sie als â€letzte Hoffnung des Planetenâ€œ verkaufen, wird Luisa Neubauer weiter ihre Show abziehen. Doch irgendwann â€“ wenn selbst ihre eigenen JÃ¼nger merken, dass sie nichts weiter als ein grÃ¼nes Hochglanzprodukt ist â€“ kÃ¶nnte ihr Stern genauso schnell verglÃ¼hen, wie sie ihn selbst angezÃ¼ndet hat. Und dann? Wird sie vielleicht doch noch ins Familienunternehmen einsteigen â€“ und sich einen neuen Slogan Ã¼berlegen: â€Nachhaltig qualmen mit Reemtsmaâ€œ? #neubauer

content: AIRPLANE WITH DOUBLE DECKERSâ€¦ for passengers Double-decker planes, or those with a multi-level cabin configuration, are primarily associated with two iconic aircraft: 1. **Boeing 747**: Known as the "Queen of the Skies," it has a partial upper deck, often used for first-class lounges or additional seating. This plane has been used by numerous countries for both passenger and cargo operations. However, its production has ceased, but it remains in service with airlines like Lufthansa and Korean Air for some passenger routes, and significantly in cargo versions by carriers like Atlas Air. - **Inside**: The upper deck of the 747 is smaller than the main cabin but often used for luxury or business class. It's like a VIP room in the sky where the elite can escape the common folk, but without the champagne fountains you'd expect in such an exclusive club. 2. **Airbus A380**: This is the full double-decker jetliner with both decks running the length of the fuselage. It's operated by airlines from countries like the UAE (Emirates), Singapore (Singapore Airlines), Australia (Qantas), and others. - **Inside**: The A380 is like a flying palace with its spacious interior. The upper deck is often where you'll find the swanky business and first-class cabins, sometimes with lounges and even shower spas, because why not freshen up at 35,000 feet? The main deck typically houses economy and premium economy. It's like having a party where the cool kids hang out upstairs, and the rest of us mingle with the snack bar downstairs. Countries where these planes operate include: - **United Arab Emirates**: Emirates is the largest operator of the A380, with Dubai International Airport as a major hub. - **Singapore**: Singapore Airlines, one of the first operators of the A380. - **France**: Air France has flown the A380, although they've been reducing their fleet. - **Germany**: Lufthansa has utilized both the A380 and 747-8 for long-haul flights. - **South Korea**: Korean Air has operated the 747 and A380 for international routes. - **Australia**: Qantas has used the A380 for routes like Melbourne to Los Angeles. The trend towards double-deckers has waned with a shift towards more fuel-efficient, twin-engine aircraft, but these giants still grace the skies in some parts of the world, offering that unique experience of flying in a plane that feels more like a vertical community than a traditional aircraft.

content: In 1987, cash-strapped American Airlines launched the AAirpass: $250,000 for unlimited lifetime first-class travel. Investment banker Steven Rothstein, a frequent flyer, bought one immediately. In 1989 he added a $150,000 companion pass that let anyone fly with himâ€”even on separate flights. From 1987 to 2008, Rothstein averaged 476 flights per year (over 10,000 total, 30 million miles). He flew to London for dinner, Tokyo for sushi, Sydney for weekendsâ€”treating planes like buses. He used the companion pass for profound kindness: spotting stranded travelers, homeless people, priests, or refugees at airports and gifting them first-class seats home. His daughter said he turned the pass into a tool for random, life-changing generosity. American Airlines sold just 66 passes (1981â€“1988), raising $16.5 million. Early on, the CEO wrote Rothstein praising his use and promising to honor the deal â€œfar into the future.â€ By 2007, facing losses, the airline created a â€œrevenue integrity unit.â€ It calculated Rothstein and one other holder were each costing >$1 million yearly. From 2005â€“2008 he booked 3,000+ segments for himself (84% canceled/no-show) and 2,700 companion segments (85% unused). Many bookings used placeholder names (â€œBag Rothstein,â€ â€œSteven Rothstein Jr.â€) because he decided at the gate whom to help. Reservations were made by phone; staff knew and never objectedâ€”some even suggested the practice. On December 13, 2008, at Chicago Oâ€™Hare, while escorting a Bosnian policeman he was flying home, Rothstein was handed a letter revoking his AAirpass for â€œfraudulent usage.â€ His 21-year unlimited life ended instantly. The airline accused him of speculative bookings and fake names. Rothstein sued for breach of contract; AA countersued for fraud. The case settled confidentially in 2012 after AAâ€™s bankruptcy. A deeper truth emerged in court: after his teenage son Josh died in 2002, many late-night bookings were grief-driven calls to familiar reservation agentsâ€”his only human contact when loneliness was unbearable. The unused tickets werenâ€™t fraud; they were a heartbroken father staying tethered to the world. American Airlines later terminated all remaining AAirpasses. Former CEO Bob Crandall admitted: â€œThe public was smarter than we were.â€ Rothstein never accepted wrongdoing but later said he had mixed feelings about ever buying the pass. It gave him freedom and the power to help thousandsâ€”yet ended in betrayal. His story is the last real unlimited lifetime airline pass: a brief era when a golden ticket actually meant forever, until corporate promises met bottom-line reality. For 10,000 flights and 30 million miles, Steven Rothstein livedâ€”and sharedâ€”a dream that no longer exists.

content: That lost sentence is fire. The decided to run the fade in the airport and call it even. 94 year old homie was the only real loser here bc he was missing his business https://t.co/NKRjnrCgJM QT @KungFuRedNeck: @GangHits The fight involving rapper Jim Jones at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport began aboard an American Airlines flight from Miami on May 4, 2024, shortly after the plane landed but before it reached the gate. Jones stood up in first class to retrieve his luggage from the overhead bin, which prompted fellow passenger James Dos Santos to confront him and push him in the chest. Jones responded by grabbing Dos Santos' arm and telling him to stop, after which Dos Santos apologized. However, another passenger, Alexander Lekht (who was traveling with Dos Santos), began screaming at Jones from his seat. Airport deputies were called to the gate due to the initial confrontation, but Jones declined to file a report at that time and proceeded to baggage claim. Lekht followed Jones and continued to harass him, making sudden movements in an attempt to provoke him further. The situation escalated into a physical altercation on a nearby escalator, where Lekht swung punches at Jones, leading Jones to throw Lekht down the escalator. Dos Santos then joined in by throwing punches at Jones as well. During the brawl, a 94-year-old bystander named James Jackson was knocked to the ground and sustained minor leg injuries, requiring transport to a hospital. Jones maintained that he acted in self-defense throughout the incident, stating, "I was minding my business and defended myself. They got what they were looking for." Surveillance footage reviewed by police corroborated his account, and no charges were filed against anyone involved, as none of the parties wished to press charges.

content: Itâ€™s humbling for the low-income passengers as theyâ€™re forced to file past the pre-boarded business class passengers, on their way to the cheap seats in the back of the plane. https://t.co/qMmgeBCoQu QT @mualphaxi: Airports these days are a perfect picture of American affluenza. The US upper-ish class has too much money, but never enough. Lots of suspicious â€œpre-boarders,â€ teens in designer clothes, $500 headphones muttering â€˜what?â€™ to flight staff. There are like 50 people in â€œboarding group 1â€ now, as well. You can see the confusion on peopleâ€™s faces whoâ€™ve clearly been boarding first for a while, who now wait 20 minutes standing just to have their spot in line! The lounges are overrun, and again, you can see the exasperation on the faces of people waiting for them, thinking theyâ€™d paid for a service and realizing that now itâ€™s like Disneyworld. Prices across the board have gone up, and demand keeps up. This is one of the effects of mass affluence, I guess. Airline taxes are as high as ever, and as a result actual â€œbudgetâ€ flights (Ã  la Ryanair) are not allowed. At this point, a budget flight is anything underâ€¦ $300? People are amazingly unforgiving. They get violent looks in their eyes when staff announce that overhead bin space will run out. For many flyers, being asked to check a bag is like being asked for one of their kidneys. So many people look at children like theyâ€™re rodents that have infiltrated the house, rather than our treasures and our future. Parents are the scapegoat of every flight. Funny enough, the TSA feels like the one thing that has gotten better. Maybe I choose my airports and flying times well, but I donâ€™t remember the last time I waited more than 15 minutes to get through. Sometimes the CLEAR line is comically longer than the regular line next to it. And for whatever reason, people will just _not_ move over to the shorter line. Itâ€™s pretty rare to see actual brawling, but you do hear about these things. As a writer and chronicler of America, this entropy interests me. Iâ€™m almost immunized from feeling the pressure, because Iâ€™ve taught myself to laugh about it and observe. I see the story, and as a result the chaos isnâ€™t so bad. And to me, mass affluence is the biggest story in the country. People who thought theyâ€™d â€œmade itâ€ are stuck in a Commons that they feel has degraded. Theyâ€™re in a race to constant fly all around the country, and even the ones with quite a bit of money are feeling the squeeze. At the Santa Barbara airport recently, about to board an upsetting expensive, 38 minute flight to San Francisco, I saw this in its purest form. Everyone flying from SB to SF is â€œrich.â€ Nearly all live in multimillion-dollar houses. And there they were, watching private jets take off through the windows, about to board a full commercial flight themselves. Affluenza. Me? I try to always feel the wonder. Isnâ€™t it amazing how quickly we can get basically anywhere? It seems so soul destroying to develop an entitlement here. The US is what it is. And itâ€™s a machine to make services widely available at a market price. The chaos begins when a lot more people get pretty wealthy; you see this same pattern in ski resorts, housing markets, etc. Already we see lots of cultural messaging encouraging people to â€œexitâ€ from all this â€” either by amassing enough money, or by voluntarily choosing slower things (trains, small towns, camping). I think weâ€™ll see more of that. What do you think of my theory?

content: #britishairways https://t.co/mhX36Neapu QT @sash_jpg: A story about @British_Airways I had a flight booked for Thursday to see my dad, who was extremely unwell with Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Sadly, on Sunday, he passed away. I contacted British Airways customer service, and they told me not to worry they could move me to an earlier flight. The only option available connected via Nairobi. As it was a 26-hour journey, I asked to upgrade to the maximum possible. I was told there was no Business Class available, despite my return ticket being Business (Club World). The agent who helped rebook the flight reassured me and specifically said, â€œDonâ€™t worry, youâ€™ll be able to use our lounges during the connection.â€ When I arrived in Nairobi, no one could tell me which lounge I was allowed to use. The British Airways team said their lounge was only available if I was upgraded to Club World again. Their connecting flight partner said I couldnâ€™t use their lounge either. None of my cards Amex, Revolut Gold, or anything else worked. I messaged British Airways repeatedly, explaining that I was stuck in the airport, hadnâ€™t eaten for two days, and was travelling immediately after losing my father. I didnâ€™t asked for any other help, I just needed somewhere to rest. There was zero empathy and no effort to resolve the situation. Almost no concern at all. Even your cabin crew were shocked that no hotel, lounge access, or basic support had been arranged for me. So thank you, British Airways. You can call yourself whatever kind of airline you want but when I needed you the most, you didnâ€™t show up. In the end I upgraded my connection flight via their partner airline directly. The lesson here: donâ€™t waste your time on loyalty. It doesnâ€™t pay nor it comes when you need it the most. And drop those Amex gold bullshit, nothing helps when itâ€™s urgent urgent.

content: @Morbidful â€œWOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be.â€ ğŸ’•Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham.

content: Someone once tried to sell me a private jet, and I told him that @Ryanair already makes me happy. I donâ€™t know when @elonmusk last flew with Ryanair. Iâ€™ve flown with them 7 times (6 on FR and 1 on RK), with the most recent on 2025-09-21. I understand why Starlink might have limited usefulness on Ryanair, given their fully economy-class cabin layout. By comparison, Iâ€™ve flown @Emirates 75 times, including 58 times in First and 15 times in Business. On the Emirates A380 First Class, passengers enjoy spacious, fully enclosed suites and large screens. With the introduction of high-speed in-flight internet, Emirates could seriously consider enabling projection from personal devices to the screen. Increasing screen resolution would further enhance the in-flight working experience, effectively turning the First Class suite into a true airborne workstation. Kris Jenner sought out wealthy men in high-end social environments in Los Angeles and through her job as a flight attendant. Specific locations and strategies mentioned in various accounts include: High-end social circles: Jenner was encouraged by her mother to frequent places where wealthy men would gather, such as exclusive golf courses and tennis courts in the Beverly Hills area. Working as a flight attendant: She worked briefly as a flight attendant for American Airlines, a job that allowed her to meet affluent individuals traveling in first class. Networking and introductions: Her high school social life involved dating older, established men. She met her first husband, the wealthy Hollywood attorney Robert Kardashian, at a horse racing track.

content: @Buma11252252 @esjesjesj @LouiseRawAuthor Yes, that's a genuine historical photo of Air France's first-class meal service aboard a Boeing 747 in 1988. It depicts the elaborate, white-glove dining typical of premium cabins back then, with uniformed attendants serving multi-course meals at individual tables. Such opulence has largely faded due to cost pressures and evolving airline economics, not just cultural shifts.

content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Singapore, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown ALOT this year, and while I don't enjoy the 14+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlines

content: Make him famous for this TOO Great guy https://t.co/VjnmOVqp4v QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. content: @DOGE__news Well, you could have bought a business class ticket and had the same thing. I can tell by your nails that you want Lufthansa treatment for Spirit fares.

Uff the ending... https://t.co/5glKUq5u37 QT @HansMokeNiemann: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed our version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.

Can't be the same Jimoh we know ğŸ˜• https://t.co/35wZoBLZfk QT @abrahamgreat: Before the last elections in Nigeria, the Senator was on course to take up roles at the United Nations and this move was genuinely backed by both Oxford and Cambridge Universities, where he has both studied and lectured. I personally sat with him in his office at Cambridge University and asked why he was going to run for election in Nigeria. The plan was for him to be on this journey of academic pursuit and then contribute his intellect on a global scale. But, his core thesis for his PhD at Cambridge in which he interviewed a least 3 living presidents of Nigeria and several parastatals, provided great insights on failed mega projects in Nigeria. He explained in his thesis and the eventual book, that since 1960, Nigeria has had over 10,000 mega projects fail. This thesis I believe attracted the relevant personnel to convince him to return to Nigeria to run for the senate and work with Mr President to drive the mandate to redevelop Nigeria, at least in stirring the legislative strategy for both reform and visionary moves for the future. In rescent times, the image of Nigeria has been under fire, not just from internal insecurities and what I call â€œapoptosisâ€, it is now imperative that Nigeria have a serious academic, global diplomacy strategic mind at the global boardrooms to have a voice that shines the light of the country than we have ever done before. That role suits well for the man who has in the past 10 years invested heavily in understanding the world from the perspective of Harvard University, London School of Economics, Cambridge University and Oxford University. All of those universities alone have confidence in Dr Ibrahim's intellect and communication skills. In one journey, we flew a 6-hour flight on British Airways and forgo all our 1st class privileges like food and a nice bed to discuss his thesis and his passion to see Nigeria's mega projects come back to life or end. To be honest, I was upgraded Business Class to First, just to continue the lectures from his thesis. content: can someone teach niemann a thing or two about paragraphs https://t.co/rE8t6yT7uj QT @HansMokeNiemann: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed our version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.

Trotz mehrerer Versuche gelang es der Crew nicht, das GerÃ¤t zu befreien, was zu wachsenden Bedenken hinsichtlich einer mÃ¶glichen Brandgefahr fÃ¼hrte. ğŸš¨ ### Experten warnen vor versteckten Gefahren ğŸ§ "Eingeklemmte Lithium-Ionen-Batterien stellen ein erhebliches Sicherheitsrisiko dar," erklÃ¤rt Prof. Dr. Klaus Weber, Experte fÃ¼r Luftfahrtsicherheit an der TU MÃ¼nchen. "Es ist nicht das erste Mal, dass ein eingeklemmtes GerÃ¤t einen Notfall verursacht," bemerkt Luftfahrtanalystin Sabine Hoffmann. "Neben den direkten Kosten fÃ¼r Treibstoff und Unterbringung kommt es zu Folgeverschiebungen im gesamten Flugplan." #Wirtschaftsfaktor ### Verhaltensempfehlungen fÃ¼r Reisende ğŸ“ Um Ã¤hnliche VorfÃ¤lle zu vermeiden, empfehlen Experten: - Elektronische GerÃ¤te wÃ¤hrend der Sitzverstellung im Blick behalten ğŸ‘€ - Bei Verlust eines GerÃ¤ts sofort das Kabinenpersonal informieren âœ‹ - Auf stark beschÃ¤digte GerÃ¤te an Bord verzichten ğŸš« - Powerbanks und Ersatzbatterien nur im HandgepÃ¤ck transportieren ğŸ§³ ### Zukunftsperspektiven: Sitzdesign und Technik ğŸ”® Flugzeughersteller arbeiten bereits an verbesserten Sitzdesigns, die solche VorfÃ¤lle vermeiden sollen. content: https://t.co/WhCyDAdnS9 https://t.co/vXYhYDYsXT QT @flightdrama: A Virginia family has filed a $200,000 federal lawsuit after alleging their KLM business class flight turned into a nightmare due to bed bugs in the cabin. The incident occurred on a transatlantic leg operated by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, booked via a Delta codeshare, while traveling from the United States to Europe. Court filings claim insects were found in the seams of business class seats just hours into the overnight flight, with repeated bites affecting both adults and children. The family alleges cabin crew discouraged discussion to avoid panic and provided limited assistance beyond isolating belongings. Medical treatment later confirmed bed bug bites, with lasting physical and emotional effects cited. The lawsuit names both KLM and Delta Air Lines, adding pressure on airlines over long haul cabin hygiene standards.

content: @iamumair_pk @0xgaut Yes, Delta Air Lines offers Bluetooth headphone connectivity for in-flight entertainment, but it's limited to first-class on Airbus A321neo aircraft. On a flight from Atlanta to Montego Bay, passengers paired wireless headphones like AirPods to seat-back screens. To use it, select the Bluetooth logo on the screen, put headphones in pairing mode, and connect. Volume is controlled via the screen. This feature isn't available in economy or on all planes, but Delta plans to expand it to more aircraft, like the A350-1000, by mid-2026. content: Hey @AirCanada @Aeroplan here is my suggestion to your new Aeroplan status overall in 2026. Subject: Suggestion for a Fairer Aeroplan Program Update Dear Air Canada Aeroplan Team, As loyal Air Canada customers, weâ€™re concerned about the upcoming changes to the Aeroplan program shifting to a spend-based model starting January 2026. While we understand the intent to reward higher spending, this change risks alienating frequent flyers who prioritize travel distance over cost, like budget-conscious long-haul travelers. We propose a hybrid approach to make the program more inclusive and rewarding for all members. For example, award points based on both dollars spent and miles flownâ€”say, 1 point per dollar spent plus 1 point per 100 miles flown, with multipliers like 1.5x for flex fares and 2x for business class. This would fairly reward both high spenders and loyal travelers racking up miles, ensuring everyone feels valued. We believe this balanced system would retain a broader range of customers, from elite frequent flyers to cost-conscious travelers, keeping Aeroplanâ€™s appeal strong. Please consider this feedback to enhance the programâ€™s fairness and inclusivity. Thank you for listening to your customers!

content: @hthieblot They often share luggage space research from the Journal of Air Transport Management (2020) shows 78% of first-class passengers prefer early boarding to secure overhead space and settle in, challenging the idea that more time on the plane is undesirable. Psychological studies, like those in Aviation Psychology and Applied Human Factors (2019), suggest early boarding reduces stress for premium passengers by alleviating last-minute rush anxiety, explaining why airlines prioritize this despite complaints. Historical shifts in airline policy, such as Lufthansa's introduction of last-boarding options for first-class in 2008, indicate growing flexibility, yet only 15% of passengers opt for it, per a 2023 IATA report, highlighting entrenched boarding norms.

content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Singapore, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown ALOT this year, and while I don't enjoy the 14+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlinesThey

content: First-Class Lavatory Windows: British Airwaysâ€™ Sky-High Surprise Picture this: Youâ€™re flying first class on a British Airways Boeing 747, luxuriating in the finer things in life, when nature calls. You make your way to the lavatory, open the door, andâ€”surprise! Thereâ€™s a window. Yes, a window. At 35,000 feet. Passengers, accustomed to the cozy privacy of windowless lavatories, were quite taken aback by this bold design choice. Particularly concerned was an Arab woman traveling to Dubai (DXB), who couldnâ€™t help but notice the conspicuous absence of blinds. Feeling a tad exposed, she voiced her concern to a nearby stewardess. â€œMadam,â€ the stewardess replied with a twinkle in her eye, â€œif some wandering pervert is climbing to the side of the aircraft at 35,000 feet, he deserves to see everything!â€ The woman couldnâ€™t help but chuckle, imagining some daredevil peeping Tom scaling the aircraft mid-flight. Perhaps heâ€™d wave through the window, give a thumbs up, and proceed to break the record for the worldâ€™s most daring peek. But letâ€™s be honestâ€”this is first class, and British Airways knows how to keep it classy, even when adding a touch of adventure to the lavatory experience. After all, if youâ€™re shelling out for a first-class ticket, why not have a loo with a view? Whether itâ€™s a spectacular sunset, a field of fluffy clouds, or just the knowledge that youâ€™re flaunting your high-altitude porcelain throne to the skies, itâ€™s a story for the grandkids. And for those still worried about privacy, fret not. The likelihood of encountering a high-flying voyeur is about as slim as finding legroom in economy. So sit back, relax, and enjoy the viewâ€”both inside and outside the lavatory. Because in the world of aviation, sometimes you just have to roll with the turbulence and laugh at the unexpected. So, next time youâ€™re flying first class on British Airways, remember to bring your sense of humor. And maybe a pair of sunglassesâ€”just in case the view gets a little too bright! ğŸ˜‰

content: @ClassicsPlanes "Lockheed L-1011 TriStar. Usually spoken of in its homeland the US as either the â€œL-One-Oh-Elevenâ€ or the â€œL-Ten-Eleven,â€ which was parodied in its declining years as L-Ten-a-Lemon and said to denote Late 10 out of 11 times; also the Tribastard and Frightstar. Swamp Buggy and Swamp Eater referred to the infamous Eastern 401 crash in the Everglades in 1972. Eastern included the TriStar in their Whisperliner fleet, and when introduced on Caribbean routes it was referred to there as el Grandote (The Big Guy) At PSA the widebody was the Mother Grinning Bird to complement the narrowbody Grinning Birds. Cabin crew at Delta called it the Tritanic, as a slight nose-up attitude in flight was thought reminiscent of the raised bow of a sinking ship. When first introduced into British Airways service, pilots called it the Tripod, and cabin crew allegedly knew it as the Big Dipper because of the increased opportunities for â€œDippingâ€ (transferring free First-Class spirits into miniatures for private re-sale in Economy) The â€œSunsetâ€ mod at BA involved replacing the lower galley and lifts on -200s to create extra freight space. The unusual semi-circle of toilets at the rear was known within Lockheed as Cannery Row (can being US slang for a toilet) and at Caledonian as Penny Lane (â€œSpending a pennyâ€ being British slang for using a toilet) The aforementioned nose-up pitch combined with urine splashes was said to produce a distinctly unpleasant smell on the TriStar, and if the lids were up and thrust-reversal applied on landing the resultant sound was said to be like â€œgunfire.â€ The noise-reducing fairing below the intake of the centre engine on the -500 was known as the Frisbee, not because of any resemblance to the throwing disc but because it was devised by Lockheedâ€™s Lloyd Frisbee. BiStar was a reference to engine failures, although it was also used more formally in relation to the unbuilt twin-engined L-1011-600 (aka the CL1600) The only military operator was the UK, who bought 6 ex British Airways L1011-500s in the immediate wake of the 1982 Falklands war, primarily for use as K.1 & KC.1 tankers; these soon became known as Tommies, possibly deriving from the rhyming slang Tommy Tanker (Wanker) A further 3 ex Pan Am -500s were ordered 2 years later as pure C.2 passenger aircraft and given the complementary name of Timmy, with the sole C.2A upgrade sometimes being referred to as Tammy. The two TriStars sent to Saudi Arabia during the first Gulf War and given â€sand pinkâ€ camouflage were known collectively as the Pink Pigs or Flying Pigs, and individually as Pinky & Perky after the childrenâ€™s TV show characters. British charter operator Court Line also had a pink TriStar, G-BAAB â€œHalcyon Breezeâ€ known within the company as the Pink Lady, operated alongside G-BAAA â€œHalcyon Daysâ€ or the Big Banana." This, and thousands more aviation nicknames, colloquialisms, changed names, airline class names, fictional names, anecdotes & fun facts, lesser-known conversions, upgrades & variant names, reporting names and naming protocols all recorded and analysed here - https://t.co/D9RExxigac

content: @Fun_Viral_Vids In 1987, American Airlines implemented a cost-saving measure that yielded impressive results. By removing just one olive from every salad served in first class, the airline saved $40,000 annually. This significant reduction was achieved through a simple yet effective adjustment to their menu. With thousands of flights and passengers daily, the cumulative cost of those extra olives added up quickly. American Airlines' decision demonstrated the importance of attention to detail and smart resource management. By streamlining their menu, the airline was able to minimize waste and maximize efficiency. This successful initiative showcases the impact of small changes on the bottom line, highlighting the value of careful planning and strategic decision-making.

content: @JeDetain Power outlets in extra legroom seats on airplanes vary by airline and aircraft. Theyâ€™re often available in premium areas like exit rows or premium economy, but itâ€™s not guaranteed. For example, American Airlines may have outlets in exit rows, Delta in First Class on select planes, and Air Canada near most seats. Check the airlineâ€™s website or SeatGuru for your flightâ€™s seat map to confirm. Outlets are typically near seats, sometimes with USB ports, but exact placement differs. Contact the airline for certainty, especially for long flights.

content: Numbers donâ€™t lie, and the poor business decisions here are undeniable. Itâ€™s hard to see how any company could justify these results. Ultimately, the impacts are clear. The companyâ€™s reputation has been damaged, and the fans have borne the burden. Ticket prices were raised, yet the outcome was deeply disappointing. Fans experienced disorganization, last-minute benefit cancellations, and even disrespect toward the thoughtful gifts they prepared. These are loyal supporters who waited years to meet the girls, only to have their love tarnished and treated carelessly by the organizers. IDF should take the time to truly digest fans' feedback and reflect. Even if they are not directly responsible for the organizerâ€™s behaviour, as the client they should have a say in how these issues are handled moving forward. Adding to this is the unfair treatment toward our girls. Visibility matters, yet while international and local media highlighted the tremendous success of the tour and the passionate support of fans, the company itself remained silent on its own social media channels. When your own artists achieve such milestones, acknowledgment should be the minimum. content: Imo, another, smaller factor that led to drop off in the number of Western carrier routes to Africa is that by 2000, the former Eastern Bloc carriers that flew routes to Africa because of Cold War reasons.. carriers like Interflug, Balkan Bulgarian, and Aeroflot.. stopped flying to Africa completely. They'd either gone out of business, unable to compete in a capitalist world or just dropped the routes because the ideological great power propaganda motivation for the routes had ceased to exist. Of course.. Western legacy carriers take on or drop routes based on primarily profit concerns, but I think that it the Cold War environment there was a certain level of motivation to maintain routes to certain African cities.. just because "the Communists" were also flying there. QT @muloongo: People made a lot of noise when British Airways exited many African markets some years back and maintained lucrative routes like South Africa and Nigeria. This picture sums up why: business class. Empty seats upfront = low margins and more expensive economy travel https://t.co/sJ36CmE11l

@coldenvy @Karanx_ My five cents. You underestimate just how much the structure of society shapes human behavior. Without institutions, without enforced norms, thereâ€™s only a fragile barrier separating civilization from the chaos of history. We get glimpses of this in war, riots, and moments of lawlessnessâ€”but for the most part, societal structure keeps people in line, adhering to an unspoken social contract. Occasionally, though, we see cracks in that structureâ€”reminders of how thin the veil really is. My brother once told me a story about watching Brazilians check in for a flight to the United States. The scene was loud and chaoticâ€”shouting, jostling, cutting in lineâ€”because in that environment, securing attention and getting what you need requires forcefulness. In a society where institutions are weaker, you have to act in your own interest because everyone else does. To someone from a highly structured society, this behavior seems aggressive, even rude. But within that system, itâ€™s simply survival. Then, something remarkable happened. The same people, upon entering the first-class lounge of American Airlines in SÃ£o Paulo, transformed instantly. Gone was the shouting, the shoving, the disorder. Inside the lounge, they adapted to the rules of a structured environmentâ€”a space governed by the quiet, orderly expectations of American or Canadian norms. The contrast was stark. This is why institutions matter. They donâ€™t just impose order; they shape behavior itself. When people talk about dismantling these structures, they should tread carefully. Because when the scaffolding of society weakens, history reminds us of what waits on the other side.

content: I made the mistake of leaving four hours between a Madrid to Heathrow and Heathrow to Atlanta business class flight. Had to change terminal from 5 to 3. From leaving the arriving plane at 5 to sitting down in the Cathay Pacific lounge with champagne took 30 minutes ğŸ˜‚ https://t.co/WnPZunKD7a QT @Noahpinion: Today, I made the mistake of flying from Dublin to Paris via London's Heathrow Airport. This was a remarkably stupid move on my part, given that London, and by extension Heathrow, is located in the failing formerly-developed country known as "the UK". I almost paid dearly for this oversight. My layover was 1 hour and 30 minutes. As soon as my flight from Dublin arrived at Terminal 2, I began looking around for my connecting flight to Paris, which was located in Terminal 5. A helpful immigration officer pointed me in the direction of a free train that I could take to Terminal 5. After walking for about 15 minutes through a labyrinthine maze of tunnels, I arrived at this train. The train required me to get a ticket for the free trip to Terminal 5. After standing in line at a machine, I pressed a button that dispensed this ticket. I then used the ticket to go through a turnstyle. Once on the platform (which was poorly labeled), I discovered -- by asking some locals -+ that the trains for Terminal 4 do not actually go to Terminal 5. (This had not been apparent from any signs or other information in the train station.) I would thus have to wait 17 minutes for the dedicated train to Terminal 5. And so wait I did. About 20 minutes later I arrived at Terminal 5, and discovered that I was in the Departures area. Despite the fact that I was transferring, I would have to go through airport security again. So I waited in line for security, watching other people struggle with the automated boarding pass scanners. Finally I reached the scanners, and when I scanned my boarding pass, it registered an error, and told me to see a British Airways employee. (Sadly, my Aer Lingus flight was operated by British Airways.) So I went to the British Airways departures counter, and after a while I found the line I was supposed to stand in. I waited 10 minutes in the line, and was finally allowed to see a British Airways employee. The British Airways employee informed me that I had already missed my flight, since boarding was at 12:15 and it was now 12:17. I argued that boarding would probably last more than two minutes, and that I might still have time to make the flight, whose departure was scheduled for 12:55. She seemed skeptical of this argument, but I finally persuaded her to help me give it a try. Returning me to the security line, the British Airways woman told me to wait in the line (which would have taken 15 minutes). I begged her to let me jump the queue, and she did, explaining my plight to a South Asian security employee who let me through the rope barrier to the front of the line. This South Asian man is actually the hero of our story. When I cut to the front of the security line, a security employee barked at me to get back. The lovely South Asian man then barked at her to let me through, and his confident air of command carried the day. I was let through, and the South Asian man even showed me how to use the security machine so that it would definitely not stop me from entering. He told me to tell his colleagues at the baggage scanner that I was allowed to jump to the front of the queue. I raced to the baggage scanning line, which looked like it would have taken an additional 20 minutes, and simply ducked under the barriers and cut to the front of the line. I apologized to the employee there and told him my flight was already boarding. He told me that in that case, I had already missed my flight, and it wasn't even worth continuing. But I told him that his colleague (the aforementioned South Asian man) had instructed me to go through security anyway, and he accepted this and let me through. I had to do an extra scan of my shoes, but made it through OK. I then ran to my gate, ducking and weaving around various travelers. When I made it to the gate, I found that the flight was still boarding, and they let me through. I then spent 20 minutes standing in line on the jetway. Naturally, my bag didn't arrive in Paris.

content: @NYC0351 @AmericanAir An upstanding airline would promptly apologize for an inoperable first-class seat and offer compensation, such as 10,000-40,000 miles or a travel voucher, as is common with American Airlines. They might also rebook the passenger on another flight or provide an upgrade if available. Documenting the issue with the crew strengthens a claim. If unsatisfied, passengers can escalate to customer service or contact the U.S. Department of Transportation. However, some feel offers like 10,000 miles are inadequate for premium tickets, preferring cash refunds or higher compensation. Outcomes vary, and clear policies are often lacking.

PMSL! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ https://t.co/DerOgp47Gi QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Muskâ€™s Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRISÂ²? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost â‚¬50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: In 1987, American Airlines saved a whopping $40,000 by removing a single olive from each salad served in first class. This seemingly insignificant detail demonstrates the power of marginal gains on a large scale. While one olive may not seem like much, when multiplied by the millions of meals served annually, it resulted in a substantial cost reduction for the airline.
