content: Lufthansaâ€™s decision to reactivate stored A340-600s and keep them flyingâ€”even after intending to retire the typeâ€”boils down to holding capacity for its First Class product and plugging gaps caused by delivery delays of newer aircraft. 1.Premium-cabin demand Since the pandemic recovery began, demand for First Class has rebounded more strongly than expected. At Munich, no other long-haul type besides the quadjet offered a full First-Class cabin until the new A350-900s with Allegra suites arrived. Reinstating five A340-600s in summer 2021 (and eventually all ten) allowed Lufthansa to quickly regain premium-cabin capacity without waiting for new-build deliveries. 2.Aircraft-delivery bottlenecks Lufthansaâ€™s wide-body modernization hinges on additional Boeing 787s and A350-900 First-Class retrofits. Production and certification delays for both programmes left the airline short of long-haul seats. Rather than suffer network cutsâ€”or deploy less-fuel-efficient 747-8sâ€”reactivating the mothballed A340-600s provided an interim supply of long-range, four-class jets to maintain its schedule. 3.Seasonal traffic peaks Each summer, Lufthansa has cycled A340-600s between storage and service to match peak long-haul demand. In Q2 of 2021, 2022, and 2023, it brought aircraft back from Teruel and Manila for summer flying before pausing them again in quieter months. In early 2023, the carrier confirmed returning its full ten-aircraft A340-600 fleet to cover growing summer traffic from both Frankfurt and Munich hubs. 4.First Class network consistency By keeping A340-600s in use, Lufthansa can guarantee First Class availability on flagship routes to New York, Hong Kong, BogotÃ¡ and other high-yield city pairsâ€”protecting revenue and loyalty-programme objectives until its next-generation premium cabins roll out. In short, Lufthansaâ€™s A340-600 comeback is a strategic stopgap: it preserves Lufthansaâ€™s premium offering and network breadth amid surging business-class demand and slower than planned arrivals of its most efficient long-haul replacements. QT @airlinevideos: Lufthansaâ€™s Airbus A340-600 takes offâ€”a sight weâ€™ll always miss at LAX! Captured during the Airline Videos Live broadcast on August 28, 2022. https://t.co/rZb1Hlj7sf

But itâ€™s generally a horrible business because every airline competes with same engines, airframes, and maintenance, so the only differentiation is really customer service and loyalty programs. margins are slim and airlines routinely plunge into bankruptcy. whatâ€™s changing is that new technologies are coming that provide credible differentiation. new engines (like Astro Mechanica and Boom), new airframes (like JetZero), new customer services (like Starlink) really do change the equation, particularly within the more profitable premium cabins. Amazon already operates commercial planes, why not start Prime Airlines? SpaceX could prob vertically integrate in ways RyanAir could not + they could uniquely offer starlink. imagine entirely new destinations only served by a specific airline, similar to cruise ships. there are new ways to capture value. golden age of travel is coming.

Just had a valuable call with a 23 y/o email agency owner from the Netherlands ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± running an operation that costs $40k/mo (staff + subscriptions). He's swimming in profit, but here's the problem: He wants to fly business class 12-15 times/yr. But when we ran the math, it wasnt mathin'. His spend won't produce the amount of pts he needs. Even with optimal multipliers on his spend, he'd earn maybe 50k points a month. That's only enough for 3-5 long-haul business class flights annually. He'd still be stuck paying cash or flying economy for the other 7-10 trips. Not exactly the lifestyle you're building for. I told him straight up, the points game doesn't work for your spend-to-travel ratio. We need a different play. So we pivoted to the Global Flyer Pass, and this is where it gets interesting. This system unlocks 97% off business class tickets on 40 airlines including United, Swiss, and Lufthansa. We're talking about booking JFK to Zurich in biz class for $216 instead of the standard $8,000. Or grabbing private jet empty legs for $100 instead of $14,000. The catch? It's standby. You need flexibility. But for a 23-year-old running a remote agency? This is fcking perfect. He gets his 15+ business class flights a year for pennies on the dollar without needing to spend millions on ads just to earn enough points. But here's the other play we're running simultaneously. He's transitioning his business from a Hong Kong structure to a US LLC for his market debut, but he has zero US credit history. That's a problem when you're trying to scale and eventually acquire competitor agencies. So we're filing for an ITIN through our community lawyer right now. Takes 6-8 weeks to establish his US credit file. Once that's locked in, we'll start opening beginner cards solely to season his credit age and build the foundation he needs to access low-interest bank capital down the line. This kid's about to fly business class everywhere he goes while simultaneously building the credit infrastructure to buy out his competition in 2-3 years. Sometimes the best strategy isn't chasing points. Sometimes it's finding the shortcut nobody talks about, then building the foundation for what comes next. If you're wondering how to unlock premium travel without waiting years to build points, or ur a foreign founder trying to crack the US credit ecosystem, let's talk.

content: @interesting_aIl Wow, what an epic shot of the Emirates A380 dwarfing that Eurowings A320 at Birmingham! The sheer scale never gets old. Fun facts: The A380 has an 79.8m wingspan (that's wider than a football pitch is long) and can carry up to 853 passengers in high density config, though Emirates typically seats around 480-615 with premium cabins, onboard showers in First Class, and a lounge bar.Birmingham (BHX) is one of the few UK airports fully equipped for regular A380 ops Emirates runs twice-daily Dubai flights, often mixing A380s with 777s. Production ended in 2021 after just 251 built, as airlines shifted to more efficient twins like the A350/787 for point-to-point routes. But Emirates still flies ~116 of them in 2025, the world's largest fleet! The A380 remains a passenger favorite for its quiet cabin and space. Long live the superjumbo!

content: @ayooladejo Last year I bought a Lufthansa ticket to London. It was the cheapest ticket I could find for business class. Now apparently you need a transit visa to use Lufthansa to go to the UK, unless you have either a valid US or Canada visa. I have both but I visited Lufthansa office in Lagos twice and also wrote to the German Consulate in Nigeria to clarify. I got a response in writing that I was fine. Now, I could have saved myself the wahala by just buying a Virgin or BA ticket to London. I couldnâ€™t afford their Business seats. But never once would it have occurred to me to abuse Nigerian passport. Iâ€™ve been traveling out of Nigeria with a Nigerian passport for 25 years. I have my own fair share of varied experiences, but it has never occurred to me once to blame Nigeria.

When I fly economy, Iâ€™m standing at check-in, desperately shifting 3 to 4 pounds in my luggage just to avoid paying extra fees. But when youâ€™re flying first class, you get an extra suitcase AND 20 more pounds per bagâ€”no hassle. Itâ€™s clear: if youâ€™ve got the money, you get treated way better. content: @AlexInAir @AirCanada Flown both air Canada and emirates business class multiple times and air Canada is horrific in comparison!

Hello! This is effectively part zero of a nine part series I will be writing over the coming days about how I am going to gain British Airways Gold Status. I will share everything about the booking process, the flights, airports, cost, and whether I think itâ€™s actually worth it. If you prefer video, I will be sharing updates & reviews over on the Smart With Points TikTok, Instagram & YouTube Kicking Things Off It is important to note that I will be starting from 40 tier points. These were primarily earned through two return journeys in economy with British Airways. I flew from London Heathrow to Manchester for one, and London Gatwick to Jersey for the other. These were my four qualifying flights which are required to progress from Bronze to Silver/Gold. I earned a further 10 tier points from a return economy trip prior with Malaysian Airlines. This was taken before I even thought about attempting a tier point run and yielded a poor TP per Â£. The Tier Point Run For my tier point run, I'll be embarking on a journey across multiple countries, flying with SriLankan Airlines and Cathay Pacific in business class. The trip kicks off with a flight from Abu Dhabi (AUH) to Colombo (CMB), where I'll have my first layover. From there, I'll head to Jakarta (CGK) and back to Colombo again, with a brief stop before returning to Abu Dhabi. This segment will be crucial for earning a good chunk of tier points as I transit multiple times through Colombo without actually stopping for a long visit. Colombo is situated just over 2000 miles between Abu Dhabi and Jakarta, making it the perfect route to earn tier points. After that, I'll fly from Abu Dhabi to Colombo and Jakarta once again, and then connect with Cathay Pacific to Hong Kong (HKG). From Hong Kong, I'll take a short hop to Taipei (TPE) and back, purely transiting through these cities. I'll then make my way back to Jakarta and switch back to SriLankan Airlines to complete the final legs of my trip, flying from Jakarta to Colombo and ending the run back in Abu Dhabi. Throughout the journey, I'll be stopping briefly in Jakarta and Taipei while purely transiting through places like Hong Kong and Colombo, all in pursuit of maximising my Avios and collecting a total of 1,480 tier points. Last Minute Changes Originally, I was due to fly AUH to CGK and back three times. Although this route earns the most tier points (560 TP x 3), I donâ€™t actually need that many for Gold. It would also mean the whole process would take a day longer, due to the SriLankan only flying 5 days a week to Jakarta. Adding the Cathay Pacific flights in there gets me just the right number of tier points whilst making it more enjoyable trip. Shout out to Matts Planet for the route idea. More over at @SmartWithPoints

content: @teslaownersSV Interesting fact about the olive! The $40,000 saved in 1987 by removing it from first-class salads was a clever move, but in context, it was just <0.001% of American Airlines' estimated $4.8â€“6.3B budget that year. It shows how small cuts can scale across millions of meals. And indeed, multiple tiny savings can add up significantly. However, thereâ€™s a tipping point. Removing one olive might not upset many, but pile on enough â€œsmallâ€ cuts, without considering the overall customer experience, and the impact becomes noticeable. Savings could be dwarfed by lost ticket sales if passengers feel the quality drop. Personally, I avoid American Airlines like the plague these days, even though Iâ€™m not a frequent first-class flyer. The cuts definitely seem to have trickled down. Iâ€™ll only choose them if thereâ€™s literally no other option. The focus on cost-cutting seems to have crossed a line for me and many others

content: Hello again! Happy Monday. Welcome to the third instalment of my British Airways Gold status adventure. Today, we're covering my journey from Abu Dhabi (AUH) to Jakarta (CGK) via Colombo (CMB). Buckle up for another rollercoaster ride of near-misses, unexpected luxuries, and the ongoing saga of e-visa complications! AUH to CMB: A Comedy of Errors (Almost) Having become somewhat of an AUH expert by now, I decided to cut it fine with my airport arrival. The Pearl Lounge, while nice, isn't exactly the height of luxury (no free cocktails or bubbly - the horror!), so I wasn't too fussed about maximising my time there. However, my nonchalance almost backfired. I'm sitting at gate 15, waiting patiently, when I spot on the board that my flight is boarding... at a completely different gate! Cue a mad dash across the terminal. I made it, but only just, earning myself the title of "Last to Board." Pro tip: Always double-check your gate! The silver lining? The plane was practically empty - only about 30 passengers total, with a mere 4 of us living it up in business class. Flight Details: â€¢ Dinner: A delightful mutton stew â€¢ Beverages: Baileys, and my now-signature peppermint tea â€¢ Sleep Quality: Excellent, thanks to familiarity with the seat setup We landed in Colombo a bit early, only to be met with a bus gate. But here's where things got interesting: they shuttled all four of us business class passengers to the terminal separately! I wasnâ€™t expecting that. Colombo Layover: The Quest for Quiet This time in Colombo, I struck gold in the SriLankan Airlines lounge. I discovered a quiet room with some seriously comfy reclining sofas. For two blissful hours, I stretched out in peace, recharging for the next leg of my journey. Once again, the lounge staff's timing was impeccable. They announced our boarding just in time for us to stroll directly onto the plane. No crowded gate lounges for us! CMB to CGK: Sleep is the New Breakfast The flight to Jakarta was considerably busier, but the travel gods smiled upon me once more - I had an open seat next to me. This time, I made the executive decision to skip breakfast in favour of more sleep (and, of course, another peppermint tea). It was definitely the right call; I felt remarkably refreshed upon arrival. Jakarta: The E-Gate Saga Continues Remember my e-gate troubles from last time? Well, they're back with a vengeance. After three failed attempts, I found myself in the unenviable position of queuing for 30 minutes at immigration. The plot thickens: The passport officer informed me that having two visas at the same time is a no-no - apparently, one activates and one cancels. However, he stamped my passport anyway, and I received an email confirming my second visa was activated. The mystery deepens! Hotel Adventures and Future Complications For this stay, I switched things up and tried a different hotel in the hope of getting more sleep. Getting there was an adventure in itself - I narrowly missed the free shuttle and decided to live on the edge by taking a Grab motorbike. Not only was it faster, but it was also way more fun! Now, here's where things get a bit tricky. I'm trying to check in for my upcoming Cathay Pacific flights to Taipei, but the online system is demanding my new Indonesian visa details. The catch? I can't apply for a new e-visa until I exit Indonesia tomorrow. It looks like I'll be heading to the airport tomorrow, fingers crossed, hoping they can check me in for the Taipei flight without these details. Looking Ahead As I sit here in my hotel room having just eaten a Nasi Goreng, contemplating the visa issue that awaits me, I can't help but feel a mix of excitement and trepidation. Will I make it to Taipei without a hitch? Will the e-gates ever accept me? And most importantly, will I ever tire of peppermint tea? Stay tuned for the next instalment of this tier point odyssey. If nothing else, it promises to be... interesting! Until next time, may your connections be smooth and your e-gates cooperative!

They were overbooked and gave us the ownerâ€™s suite for free!â€ â€œYeah, yeah,â€ muttered the hairdresser. â€œBut you didnâ€™t see President Trump.â€ â€œActually,â€ my wife said, â€œA secret service agent tapped me on the shoulder and asked if Iâ€™d like to meet him privately.â€ â€œFive minutes later, President Trump walked in, shook my hand, and spoke to me.â€ â€œOh really?â€ sneered the hairdresser. â€œWhat did he say?â€ My wife smiled and replied, â€œWho the hell did your hair, that looks like sh*t, what a loser!â€

content: We have a post abundance economic culture. Britain and most countries in the EU are increasingly becoming post-prosperity economies where the embers of past success are flickering out. None of it needs to be this way. These are choices that people who should know better are making. It can change. It can be turned around. But it will require a clear philosophy that embraces the vitality of freedom, patriotism, personal responsibility, free markets, and energy abundance. QT @albieamankona: This is genuinely embarrassing. On a short-haul @airindia flight (Bombay to Goa), economy passengers are served hot food. Business class gets hot food and a genuinely premium seat. Meanwhile, @British_Airwaysâ€™ European â€œBusiness Classâ€ now offers no hot food at all and a seat that is literally identical to economy, save for a blocked middle seat and a curtain. At this point, BAâ€™s short-haul â€œBusinessâ€ product isnâ€™t premium travel. It is premium pricing for cosmetic differences. The only material advantage over @easyJet is Heathrow, not the onboard experience. For a flag carrier that still trades on heritage and brand prestige, this is a remarkable act of self-degradation.

content: Emirates is doing exactly what I predicted. Miles and points have flooded the system, eroding the exclusivity of luxury travel. Other airlines, Qatar, Singapore, BA, Lufthansa, have all quietly cut perks on reward seats. Emirates took it further: no chauffeur, no lounge, no baggage, and now bans on children in first class, with business likely next. The message is clear: if youâ€™re not paying cash, youâ€™re not a priority or are you the customer they want in their premium cabins. Airlines donâ€™t profit from your points flights, so theyâ€™re taking back control. If, like me, youâ€™re sitting on 500k+ points, you need to get strategic. My go-to is the hybrid cash + points strategy, using points to offset the cash cost of premium cabins while keeping all the perks. It stretches points further and still gives you the full luxury experience without breaking the bank.

This new policy just adds to the divide. Itâ€™s hard to buy into the idea that â€œall humans are equalâ€ when itâ€™s obvious that the more you pay, the better your experience is.

content: Hi there - I would like to complain about an experience I am currently having on flight 2184 CLT-SFO. Iâ€™ve flown this route dozens of times for work in the past year, mostly in first class but sometimes in economy as well. I am in seat 10A today, a window seat. There is a non-rev American Airlines captain in the middle seat and another larger passenger in the aisle seat who probably should have purchased two seats All of a sudden, the captain in the middle seat gruffly tells me that the armrest is for use only by the middle seat, and that he should have access to both arm rests. I politely respond that Iâ€™m only occupying my seat and ask why heâ€™s being so rude. He responds â€œbecause Iâ€™m dealing with this situation (pointing to the overweight passenger in the aisle seat) and youâ€™re fucking pushing into my armâ€ to which I responded politely: Iâ€™m staying in my seat. The captain then responds â€œI can get a flight attendant and I promise you theyâ€™ll take my sideâ€ to which I responded â€œprobably so, since youâ€™re crewâ€ and he said â€œIâ€™m the captain?â€ Question- is this acceptable behavior from an American Airlines captain non-revving? This captain is still sitting next to me in 10B and frankly Iâ€™m afraid to say anything else because of his threats to get the flight attendants involved and how â€œthey will take his sideâ€. Use of the F word and cursing as well is unbecoming of an airline captain. Iâ€™m not sure how to proceed but I am planning to write a letter to Robert Issom as well. I am hoping the captain is just having a bad day and itâ€™s not of a reflection of who he truly is, because I would be afraid to fly on a plane he is flying in the mood that he is in at the moment.

content: In 1987, Steve Rothstein made a decision that seemed almost outrageous at the time: he paid \$250,000 for American Airlinesâ€™ unlimited â€œgolden ticket,â€ granting him free first-class flights for life. On top of that, he purchased a \$150,000 companion pass so he could bring anyone along. For Steve, travel wasnâ€™t about collecting miles or rewardsâ€”it was about freedom without limits, and he used it to the fullest. Over the years, Rothstein booked more than 10,000 flights, sometimes hopping on a plane just to have lunch in another state before returning home the same day. He was known for his generosity, often giving away trips to strangers, helping homeless individuals reunite with their families, or booking seats for companions who never showed up. His unusual habits made him both a legend and a financial headache, as American Airlines eventually calculated that he had cost them over \$21 million. In 2008, the airline revoked his pass, accusing him of misuse. But Rothstein fought back, pointing to the binding contract he had purchased decades earlier. The courts sided with him, and his golden ticket remained valid. Today, Steve Rothstein is remembered not only as the most extraordinary frequent flyer but also as a symbol of how one small clause in a contract can unlock the entire world. Â© Aviation History #archaeohistories

content: @animatedclouds @BGatesIsaPyscho Airbus has no confirmed plans for standing-only seats in 2026, despite earlier concepts in 2003 and 2006. Recent focus is on premium seating, like double-level designs, not standing options. Standing seats could lower costs and increase capacity for short flights, but safety risks during turbulence, passenger discomfort, and lack of regulatory approval make them unlikely. Airlines are prioritizing premium economy and first-class upgrades, as seen with Emirates and British Airways, suggesting standing seats aren't a current priority.

content: https://t.co/B8dhO8N3of https://t.co/bnrisRTarY QT @EUAITaxonomy: I talked to a startup in Berlin this morning. The CEO, Kristof, needed to attend a meeting in London tomorrow. He showed me his itinerary: EasyJet, BER to LHR. Flight time: 1h 50m. "Kristof," I said, shaking my head. "Have you learned nothing about the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive obligations?" "Short-haul aviation is Climate Arson." I presented him with my new, mandatory "Multi-Modal Low-Carbon Transit Protocol." You board a FlixBus at Berlin ZOB at 04:15 AM. For 13 hours, you will sit in seat 34C, next to a man who smells intensely of damp wool and unfiltered cigarettes, eating hard-boiled eggs out of a plastic bag. You transfer at Rotterdam to an overnight ferry. The North Sea is rough in December. Seasickness is just weakness leaving the body. Finally, you take a local commuter train into London, arriving exactly 29 hours after you departed. He looked pale. "But I'll miss the meeting. I'll be exhausted." "You will be exhausted," I agreed. "But you will be compliant.â€ He left for the bus station, dragging his suitcase like a condemned man. My work here was done. I took a taxi to Brandenburg Airport. I flew Business Class back to Brussels. My time is too valuable for buses. I have regulations to enforce. ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º

Let's start with Akara, which means 'I count' (Aka) and then 'I buy' (ra). Please fact-check me: Akara is the most popular street food in Brazil and Cuba and is also one of the most widely accepted street foods in Nigeria. In Brazil, it is known as Akaraje, which means 'I count' (Aka), 'I buy' (ra), and 'I eat' (je). Then, you have Olele, which the Lukumi nicknamed Moin-moin. Moin-moin is now served globally as a breakfast dish because of its high protein and slow digestion, which makes it filling and lasting. Another Lukumi Yoruba street food is Dodo Ikire. It originated from Ikire in Osun State, but with the British colonisation of Nigeria, it spread to Lagos and environs, where it simply became known as Dodo. This fried plantain dish is one of the most popular street foods in the Caribbean, where it was taken by the Lukumi enslaved people. From there, it has become world famous and is today even served to First Class passengers on British Airways as a delicacy. Akara, Moin-moin, and dodo are so good and delicious that they are now the most popular street foods in Nigeria's six geopolitical zones. This means that anybody who insults Lukumi Yoruba cuisine also insults their own ethnicity, which also prefers Lukumi street food. Finally, I sponsored an Amala hangout in Enugu last November, which was jam-packed. I can send you photos. The media covered it. If Amala is as nasty as you depict, the hangout wouldn't have been a success. Nedu, I am telling you and those who think like you all these things to make you understand that if any street food puts Nigeria on the map, it is Lukumi Yoruba street food, followed closely by the Hausa delicacy, Suya. As such, it would not be in Nigeria's best interest for you and your ilk to denigrate our cuisine to the world as your insulting and fallacious image depicts. Thanks again, and may God give you wisdom. #TableShaker

content: sat next to a guy in business class to tokyo asked what he does "i fly 30 times a year for FREEâ€ thought he worked for an airline nopeâ€¦ he figured out American airlines points are fucking BROKEN if you stack them right now I havenâ€™t paid for flights in years Here's what he showed me: The airline points game is rigged in your favor if you know which cards to stack and which portals to abuse American Airlines miles are the cheat code for international travel and almost nobody uses them correctly Here's the play: AA miles transfer 1:1 to partners like Qatar, Cathay Pacific, Japan Airlines. A business class seat to Asia that costs $8,000 cash? 70,000 miles. That's worth $0.11 per point when you redeem smart Now here's where it gets unethical: Every online purchase you make should go through the AA shopping portal first. Best Buy, Nike, Walmart, Apple - they're all on there. You're getting 2-15x miles on purchases you were making anyway $5,000 in normal spending = 25,000+ bonus miles = free domestic flight But the real players stack it: Open Citi AA Business card (80k bonus miles after $4k spend) Open Barclays AA Business (50k bonus miles) Run all business expenses through portal Pay suppliers through cards before liquidating Within 6 months you're sitting on 200,000+ miles without trying I know a guy who hasn't paid for a flight in 4 years. Books business class to Europe twice a year for "work trips" that are actually just vacations. Puts clients on economy while he's sipping champagne in the front The points cost him nothing. The flex is priceless Most people earn miles and let them expire. Or redeem them for toasters like idiots. Or fly economy when the same miles could get them flatbed seats Stop flying like you're broke when credit card companies are literally begging to send you to Bali for free

content: Skytrax World's Best First Class Airlines list for 2024 is out! So, Avgeeks, how many of these have you covered? This list sparked my curiosityâ€”how many of these can we actually fly at discounted rates? Be it through airmiles from credit cards, buying miles, earning elite statuses, or even snagging a cheap revenue deal. Iâ€™ve already flown the top one on the list, SQ, and have bookings with Emirates. Plus, I'm planning redemptions on Qatar and Swiss. But I was surprised to see Saudia on here; I didnâ€™t expect it, and I noticed EVA didnâ€™t make the cut! I do have some doubts about this list, though. For example, as far as I know, Oman Air has dropped their First Class and replaced it with the Business Studio. So, I'm not sure if theyâ€™re even flying First Class anymore. Some of these redemptions are tricky. Air France took second place, even beating Emirates, but getting into AFâ€™s La Premiere isnâ€™t easy. You can only book it with Flying Blue miles, and only if youâ€™re a FB Plat or Ultimate. Thanks to @saketreddy for sharing a way to achieve FB Plat status: Accor Diamond -> Qatar Plat (after one revenue flight) -> FB Plat (status match). Even then, you'd need around 150k FB miles for a La Premiere ticket from CDG to the US. As for Saudia, it might seem accessible, but Saudia FC can only be booked with Korean Skypass miles, costing roughly 160k for JED-JFK for roundtrip and those seats are rare and tough to book! Similarly, Garudaâ€™s First Class canâ€™t be booked with anything but Garuda miles. If you have the same itch to experience as many of these First Class products as possible, letâ€™s connect! No paid consultation hereâ€”just some serious Avgeek planning. Only DM if youâ€™re committed, as this might involve spending on credit cards, buying miles, or a bit of creative routing. Not all of them fly from India, so keep that in mind too. #AvGeek #FirstClass #Skytrax2024 #TravelHacks #PointsAndMiles #FrequentFlyer #LuxuryTravel #AwardTravel #SkyHighAspirations #ccgeek #ccgeeks

content: $DAL Delta Air Lines reported a stronger-than-expected profit for the last three months of 2024 and predicted even better earnings for the start of 2025. The company said demand for premium travel, like first-class and business-class seats, has been growing quickly as more people are willing to pay for extra comfort. This helped Deltaâ€™s ticket sales increase faster than expected, and its shares reached a record high. The airline also explained that fewer available seats on flights have led to higher ticket prices, which has boosted its earnings. Deltaâ€™s CEO, Ed Bastian, said the airline industry is getting stronger financially and expects this positive trend to continue. Delta believes 2025 will be a record-breaking year for profits, thanks to higher prices and strong demand for travel. The company said travelers are still willing to pay for tickets, even with prices rising, and a strong U.S. dollar is making international trips cheaper for Americans. Delta also expects flights between the U.S. and Europe to bring in a lot of money this year. Even though recent wildfires in Los Angeles slightly hurt sales, they arenâ€™t expected to impact Deltaâ€™s overall performance. With earnings predicted to be higher than ever, analysts are calling Deltaâ€™s future outlook very promising.

content: I was super elite with air canada for 6 years. I flew for comfort because when i landed I was expected to be on. Execution > Posing https://t.co/XnzcSkQUU1 QT @kylematthewsceo: Business tip; Whenever you are flying commercial, especially in business/first class, always wear your best business suit & tie combo (business formal). When someone walks on the plane in a great suit, white dress shirt & clean tie, I always think to myself, â€œI wonder what that guy/gal does for a living.â€ (Obviously no tie for the ladies ;)) Itâ€™s human nature. When I was 22, and now that I am 42, I always find myself wanting ask him/her â€œhey, what do you do for a living?â€ If you are in commercial real estate, especially brokerage, by dressing your absolute professional best, people will ask you â€œwhat do you do for a living?â€, and thatâ€™s all you need to get the conversation started. In business/first class, there is a real chance they are in the real estate business, but an even better chance they know someone in the real estate industry, someone who can be your client one day. It is an easy way to network and meet new people, you just have to give a little more effort to dress up and eschew your â€œI donâ€™t give a sh*tâ€ sweat pants and F-U hoodie. This also works in coach, just to a lesser degree. Combine the professional clothes with a clean shave, combed hair, and I hate to admit, yes a nice watch helps, at minimum you will get looks, and in all likelihood the person sitting next to you will have to askâ€¦ â€œhey, what do you do for a living?â€

content: @Fahadnaimb Emirates: Full-Service Luxury Model, and even in economy, the cabin service and confort is from another planetğŸ‘ Emirates operates as a premium, long-haul airline focused on high-end service, comfort, and a hub-and-spoke network centered in Dubai. This requires significantly more staff per aircraft. -Large cabin crews for multi-class service â€” Emirates flies widebody aircraft (mostly Airbus A380s and Boeing 777s, with ~252 aircraft in service as of late 2025). Flights often feature First Class, Business Class, Premium Economy, and Economy, with amenities like onboard showers (on A380s), lounges, gourmet meals, and extensive entertainment. This demands higher crew-to-passenger ratiosâ€”typically 20+ cabin crew per flight on an A380. -Extensive ground and support staff â€” The Emirates Group (which includes the airline, ground handling via dnata, catering, engineering, and more) employs around 121,000â€“125,000 people total. Many roles support premium operations, such as dedicated lounges, chauffeurs, catering facilities, and global sales/network teams. -Long-haul operations â€” Fewer daily flights per aircraft but longer durations mean staff are spread across fewer cycles, and the focus is on quality over volume. Current figures (as of late 2025): ~252 passenger aircraft and ~125,000 group employees â†’ roughly 496 employees per aircraft if including the full group, but even airline-specific staff is much higher than low-cost peers. Older data often cited ~200â€“250 when including group operations. Ryanair: Ultra-Low-Cost Efficiency Model Ryanair prioritizes minimal costs, high utilization, and point-to-point short-haul flights across Europe to offer the lowest fares. - Lean operations and high aircraft utilization â€” Ryanair's fleet (600â€“620 Boeing 737s in 2025) flies short routes with quick turnarounds (25â€“30 minutes), allowing 6+ flights per day per aircraft. This maximizes productivity with fewer planes and staff needed overall. - Minimal service and staffing â€” Single-class economy (high-density seating, 189â€“230 seats per plane), no free meals/drinks, limited amenities, and charges for extras. Cabin crews are smaller (6â€“8 per flight), and many functions (e.g., cleaning, check-in) are outsourced or passenger-self-service. - Focused workforce â€” ~26,000â€“27,000 employees (mostly pilots and cabin crew), with high productivity. No large ground handling/catering subsidiaries bloating numbers. - Standardization â€” All-Boeing 737 fleet reduces training/maintenance staff needs. Current figures: ~600+ aircraft and ~26,000 employees â†’ ~43 employees per aircraft. Why the Ratio Differs So MuchFull-service airlines like Emirates invest heavily in passenger experience, requiring more labor-intensive operations (e.g., more crew per passenger, elaborate catering, global support). Low-cost carriers like Ryanair strip out frills, outsource where possible, and maximize aircraft/crew efficiency to keep costs (and fares) low. These ratios are rough averages and can vary by how "employees" are counted (airline-only vs. group, including contractors). The core explanation holds: service level and operational model drive the massive gap.

content: @EvaHermanEx_ARD Die Klimaprinzessin mit Doppelmoral Es gibt Menschen, die kÃ¤mpfen fÃ¼r eine gerechtere Welt. Und dann gibt es Luisa Neubauer, die das Wort â€Kampf" mit â€Instagram-Filter" verwechselt. Sie ist das deutsche Gesicht von Fridays for Future, eine Art Greta Thunberg mit WLAN und Lufthansa-Kundenkarte. Ihr grÃ¶ÃŸter Beitrag zur Gesellschaft? Moralpredigten mit erhobenem Zeigefinger, wÃ¤hrend sie selbst in einer Komfortzone lebt, von der normale Menschen nur trÃ¤umen kÃ¶nnen. Neubauer verkauft sich als Stimme der Jugend, als letzte Hoffnung des Planeten â€“ doch unter der OberflÃ¤che findet sich weniger Ideologie als in einer Werbekampagne fÃ¼r nachhaltige Smoothies. Die Erbin aus Zwangsarbeit â€“ Moralische Ãœberlegenheit auf Kosten der Geschichte Luisa Neubauer spricht oft Ã¼ber Gerechtigkeit, doch ihre eigene Familie hat ihr VermÃ¶gen nicht gerade mit Fairtrade-Kaffee oder Bio-Avocados verdient. Ihre Familie ist Teil des Reemtsma-Clans, einem Zigarettenimperium, das wÃ¤hrend der NS-Zeit durch Zwangsarbeit riesige Gewinne erzielte. Nun gut, kann ja keiner was fÃ¼r seine Familie, oder? Doch wenn man sich selbst als moralische Instanz aufspielt, wÃ¤re ein MindestmaÃŸ an Selbstreflexion nicht zu viel verlangt. Neubauer jedoch schweigt zu diesem Kapitel lieber â€“ offenbar ist sie zu sehr damit beschÃ¤ftigt, anderen Leuten zu erklÃ¤ren, wie sie ihr Leben zu fÃ¼hren haben. Der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger â€“ mit Filterblase und PR-Team Neubauer hat ein Talent: Sie verkauft grÃ¼ne Ideologie wie ein Tech-Startup CEO seine neueste App. Einfache LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r komplexe Probleme (â€Einfach aufhÃ¶ren mit fossilen Energien, dann klappt das!"). Panik als Dauermodus (â€Die Welt brennt, wir mÃ¼ssen sofort handeln â€“ auÃŸer, wenn ich zum nÃ¤chsten Event fliege!"). Junge Leute mit utopischen Versprechen einfangen, wÃ¤hrend sie selbst im Luxus lebt. Sie ist der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger von Hameln, nur dass sie statt einer FlÃ¶te einen Twitter-Account und ein ARD-Mikrofon hat. WÃ¤hrend sie mit entrÃ¼cktem Blick und dramatischen Worten die Apokalypse verkÃ¼ndet, marschiert ihre Gefolgschaft in Richtung wirtschaftlicher SelbstzerstÃ¶rung â€“ und klatscht dabei begeistert. Fliegen, Feiern, Fordern â€“ Klima-Aktivismus auf First-Class-Niveau Einer ihrer bekanntesten â€Ausrutscher" war die Diskussion um ihre eigenen Flugreisen. WÃ¤hrend sie anderen vorschreibt, dass Fliegen bÃ¶se ist, jettete sie selbst frÃ¶hlich durch die Weltgeschichte. Ihre Antwort? â€Ich hatte ja keine Wahl." Genau. Weil es ja auch keine ZÃ¼ge gibt. Oder Videokonferenzen. Oder einen Funken Konsequenz in ihren eigenen Forderungen. Neubauer lebt in einem Widerspruchskosmos, in dem fÃ¼r sie selbst andere Regeln gelten als fÃ¼r die â€dummen Massen". WÃ¤hrend sie sich an Kohlekraftwerken festklebt, um â€die Zukunft zu retten", mÃ¼ssen normale BÃ¼rger schauen, wie sie mit explodierenden Energiepreisen klarkommen. GrÃ¼ne Heuchelei auf hÃ¶chstem Niveau Neubauer ist die Inkarnation der grÃ¼nen Doppelmoral. Von Reemtsma-Geld profitieren, aber Kapitalismus abschaffen wollen. Fliegen, aber Flugreisen fÃ¼r andere verteufeln. GrÃ¼nen Kommunismus fordern, aber selbst luxuriÃ¶s leben. WÃ¤hrend sie den Untergang der Welt predigt, macht sie sich ihre eigene Zukunft goldgrÃ¼n: BuchvertrÃ¤ge, Medienauftritte, Lobbytreffen â€“ ein Aktivismus, der vor allem einem Zweck dient: ihrer eigenen Karriere. Das Fazit: Klima-Heilige oder clevere GeschÃ¤ftsfrau? Luisa Neubauer ist kein Umweltengel. Sie ist eine perfekt inszenierte PR-Maschine. Ihre Kampagne hat mit echter Wissenschaft oder nachhaltiger Politik so viel zu tun wie ein Tesla mit Umweltschutz â€“ klingt gut, sieht gut aus, ist aber am Ende doch nur Marketing. Die Frage ist: Wie lange lassen sich die Leute noch tÃ¤uschen? Solange die Kameras blitzen und die Medien sie als â€letzte Hoffnung des Planeten" verkaufen, wird Luisa Neubauer weiter ihre Show abziehen. Doch irgendwann â€“ wenn selbst ihre eigenen JÃ¼nger merken, dass sie nichts weiter als ein grÃ¼nes Hochglanzprodukt ist â€“ kÃ¶nnte ihr Stern genauso schnell verglÃ¼hen, wie sie ihn selbst angezÃ¼ndet hat. Und dann? Wird sie vielleicht doch noch ins Familienunternehmen einsteigen â€“ und sich einen neuen Slogan Ã¼berlegen: â€Nachhaltig qualmen mit Reemtsma"?

content: @JeffWalker1776 Airline food gets a bad rap, but itâ€™s a mixed bag. Economy class meals are often bland due to mass production and cabin conditions like low humidity, which dulls taste buds by up to 30%. Airlines add extra salt and spices to compensate, but many still find it lacking. Premium classes, however, get gourmet upgradesâ€”think roasted sirloin on American Airlinesâ€™ long-haul flights. Safetyâ€™s tight with strict standards, though rare incidents like moldy meals on a Delta flight spark concern. Airlines are investing in better food, especially for first class, but economy options lag, reflecting cost priorities.

content: @Astrancia7370 @Kashou_Kashou @PasHenFr @MickaelLaffont That video youâ€™re laughing about seems staged. No credible reports match the story of a woman complaining about a guy in a MAGA cap getting moved to first class. The actingâ€™s off, and the plane type changes mid-video, suggesting edits for clicks. Real fights over MAGA hats on planes have happened, like a 2024 British Airways incident where two women were removed after clashing over one, or a 2017 United flight where a disruptive MAGA hat wearer got kicked off. content: $DAL Delta Air Lines had a better start to the year than many people expected, even though fewer people are taking trips for fun within the U.S. High prices and lower confidence in the economy made some travelers, especially those who look for the cheapest seats, decide not to fly as much. This caused a 5% drop in domestic travel demand. Because of that, Delta is being careful and doesnâ€™t plan to add more flights later this year like they originally thought. But not all parts of the business are strugglingâ€”Delta made more money from people buying first-class or premium tickets, and their loyalty program with American Express brought in a record $2 billion. Delta is also doing well in international travel, which makes up about 40% of their business. Places like the Pacific region saw a 16% jump in travel demand, helping balance out the slower domestic market. Even though Delta is unsure about the rest of 2025, especially with the new tariffs causing problems for global trade, they still expect decent results in the second quarter. Lower fuel prices are also helping the airline save money. It looks like this year will be tough for airlines, but Deltaâ€™s mix of premium, international, and loyalty program income may help it do better than others.

content: Want a flight with excellent service and benefits, fly @porterairlines First class service at reasonable rates. I will only use Porter now as long as they go where I need. They are increasing 'where they fly to' often. https://t.co/USGk2JuaOU QT @McCurdy1987: Hi @WestJet We need to talk. I'm not sure what's going on with you, but you're slipping hard. My wife and I paid for premium seats in both directions on our flights (one from YEG to YHZ the other from YYZ to YEG), and in both cases at the last minute our jets were swapped out for former Swoop aircraft with no leg room, no premium seats, no in-flight entertainment (in one direction, the other only because it was an ancient WestJet interior and still had WiFi) and barely any of the other perks we paid for. I booked these seats so my wife and I would travel comfortably for our relatively long flights (5+ hours and 4+ hours respectively). I paid for an extra night hotel specifically so I could fly premium and treat my wife to an improved experience. Other personal costs have been incurred for me that I was happy to pay, just to have the premium experience. I have been a customer for over 20 years and have flown with you to the near complete exclusion of other Airlines during that time. I have advocated others to use you for both business and pleasure. I have been an RBC Westjet World Elite customer for years as well. I've waited on hold twice for an hour each time and never managed to speak to a human being. The credit you told me to apply for two weeks ago because of this inconvenience the first time? Still not processed. (This should be AUTOMATIC, and the customer should not have to lift a finger unless they feel the credit isn't sufficient). Now I need to file another one for today. If I wanted a ULCC experience, I would have booked one. Oh yeah, and my flight was delayed to boot. Your only saving grace is that your flight attendants continue to deliver exemplary service (shoutout to the Service Lead, Victor on the YYZ-YEG flight today) making the best of a not ideal situation. The bulk of the Premium customers on my flight were not happy with the situation including of the other premium customers on that flight told me he'd been waiting 43 days for a credit for a similar downgrade from a previous flight. Does that really seem acceptable? I rarely publicize my frustrations, however you have broken my trust, and that is not easily regained, also you are impossible to get ahold of. Needless to say after this trip I am seriously considering canceling my @RBC @Westjet Mastercard and ceasing to use WestJet for both business and personal travel. I get that profit is the only interest of your company now, but it's hard to make a profit without customers. I am far from the only person who has experienced this recently. How the once mighty have fallen.

content: Most credit card affiliates hard-sell Chase cards at the expense of far superior loyalty currencies- at great peril to you, the consumer-slash-points-redemption archetype. Among the best use cases for international business class flights using Chase points has been for transferring to Aeroplan, which unlocks Lufthansa and Swiss awards. This is no longer true. Lufthansa group now reserves the majority of its award inventory for its proprietary Miles and More program. Chase points cannot transfer to Miles and More, which means these lie-flats cannot be booked using Chase points. My award booking client is traveling back to US from Europe on New Yearâ€™s holiday weekend. Lufthansa and Swiss. Here are her options on Swiss/Lufthansa: TL/DR- there are none. Lufthansa group holds back all the award inventory for its own program members. True- Chase points unlock Air France/KLM (high points/fees) and British Airways (high fees)- but my clientâ€™s specific city typically offers scarce award availability. Anyone selling you credit cards without asking your specific travel plans is chasing quotas and commissions- most likely performing a disservice to you. Never lock yourself into a single points scheme without knowing its blind spots.

content: ğŸ¤£ğŸ˜‚ https://t.co/1gvtoyCRbL QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Muskâ€™s Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRISÂ²? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost â‚¬50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: @DefiantLs Here are The Facts so you donâ€™t have to waste your time: American Airlines Flight Attendant Pleads Guilty to Recording Underage Girls in Airplane Bathrooms, Faces Up to 20 Years Estes Carter Thompson III January 2024 Lynchburg, Virginia Facts of the Case: Estes Carter Thompson III, a 37-year-old former American Airlines flight attendant from Charlotte, North Carolina, was involved in a disturbing incident on September 2, 2023, aboard American Airlines Flight 1441 from Charlotte Douglas International Airport to Boston Logan International Airport. While working as a flight attendant, Thompson escorted a 14-year-old girl to the first-class lavatory after she found the main cabin restroom occupied. He entered the bathroom beforehand, claiming he needed to wash his hands. The girl discovered an iPhone taped to the underside of the toilet seat lid with red stickers, which Thompson had placed to secretly record her. She took photos of the setup and reported it to her parents, who alerted the crew. The captain then notified law enforcement. Upon landing in Boston, authorities investigated and arrested Thompson later in January 2024 in Lynchburg, Virginia. A search of Thompsonâ€™s iCloud account revealed recordings of four additional underage girls (aged 7, 9, 11, and 14) using airplane restrooms on previous flights, along with hundreds of AI-generated sexually explicit images of children and a photo of a 9-year-old unaccompanied minor asleep in her seat. Thompson admitted to using the hidden iPhone to record the girls and collecting a massive trove of child pornography. Outcome: On March 6, 2025, Thompson pleaded guilty in federal court to two counts of sexual exploitation of children and attempt, as well as possession of child pornography and attempt. He faces up to 20 years in prison for the child exploitation charges, with sentencing scheduled for June 2025. The exact sentence has not yet been determined as of March 8, 2025.

content: I enjoy these more than any European should. I will turn myself in immediately. https://t.co/dCjjmsKj3W QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Muskâ€™s Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRISÂ²? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost â‚¬50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: Have unlimited staff ticket access on all except 1, 5, 15, 17-20 ğŸ‘» https://t.co/IYbS7bJlU9 QT @VoyageBliss: Skytrax World's Best First Class Airlines list for 2024 is out! So, Avgeeks, how many of these have you covered? This list sparked my curiosityâ€”how many of these can we actually fly at discounted rates? Be it through airmiles from credit cards, buying miles, earning elite statuses, or even snagging a cheap revenue deal. Iâ€™ve already flown the top one on the list, SQ, and have bookings with Emirates. Plus, I'm planning redemptions on Qatar and Swiss. But I was surprised to see Saudia on here; I didnâ€™t expect it, and I noticed EVA didnâ€™t make the cut! I do have some doubts about this list, though. For example, as far as I know, Oman Air has dropped their First Class and replaced it with the Business Studio. So, I'm not sure if theyâ€™re even flying First Class anymore. Some of these redemptions are tricky. Air France took second place, even beating Emirates, but getting into AFâ€™s La Premiere isnâ€™t easy. You can only book it with Flying Blue miles, and only if youâ€™re a FB Plat or Ultimate. Thanks to @saketreddy for sharing a way to achieve FB Plat status: Accor Diamond -> Qatar Plat (after one revenue flight) -> FB Plat (status match). Even then, you'd need around 150k FB miles for a La Premiere ticket from CDG to the US. As for Saudia, it might seem accessible, but Saudia FC can only be booked with Korean Skypass miles, costing roughly 160k for JED-JFK for roundtrip and those seats are rare and tough to book! Similarly, Garudaâ€™s First Class canâ€™t be booked with anything but Garuda miles. If you have the same itch to experience as many of these First Class products as possible, letâ€™s connect! No paid consultation hereâ€”just some serious Avgeek planning. Only DM if youâ€™re committed, as this might involve spending on credit cards, buying miles, or a bit of creative routing. Not all of them fly from India, so keep that in mind too. #AvGeek #FirstClass #Skytrax2024 #TravelHacks #PointsAndMiles #FrequentFlyer #LuxuryTravel #AwardTravel #SkyHighAspirations #ccgeek #ccgeeks

What a beautiful soul ğŸ’– https://t.co/qb5AagovvR QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I canâ€™t help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say itâ€™s just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesnâ€™t know Iâ€™m back. They tell me that Iâ€™m going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. Iâ€™m pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, â€œHow much is it?â€ They tell him $50 and he says â€œI got it.â€ Iâ€™m astonished and tell him itâ€™s fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this manâ€™s generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. Iâ€™m crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as heâ€™s sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." ğŸ’• Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

Neubauer verkauft sich als Stimme der Jugend, als letzte Hoffnung des Planeten â€“ doch unter der OberflÃ¤che findet sich weniger Ideologie als in einer Werbekampagne fÃ¼r nachhaltige Smoothies. Die Erbin aus Zwangsarbeit â€“ Moralische Ãœberlegenheit auf Kosten der Geschichte Luisa Neubauer spricht oft Ã¼ber Gerechtigkeit, doch ihre eigene Familie hat ihr VermÃ¶gen nicht gerade mit Fairtrade-Kaffee oder Bio-Avocados verdient. Ihre Familie ist Teil des Reemtsma-Clans, einem Zigarettenimperium, das wÃ¤hrend der NS-Zeit durch Zwangsarbeit riesige Gewinne erzielte. Nun gut, kann ja keiner was fÃ¼r seine Familie, oder? Doch wenn man sich selbst als moralische Instanz aufspielt, wÃ¤re ein MindestmaÃŸ an Selbstreflexion nicht zu viel verlangt. Neubauer jedoch schweigt zu diesem Kapitel lieber â€“ offenbar ist sie zu sehr damit beschÃ¤ftigt, anderen Leuten zu erklÃ¤ren, wie sie ihr Leben zu fÃ¼hren haben. Der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger â€“ mit Filterblase und PR-Team Neubauer hat ein Talent: Sie verkauft grÃ¼ne Ideologie wie ein Tech-Startup CEO seine neueste App. Einfache LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r komplexe Probleme (â€Einfach aufhÃ¶ren mit fossilen Energien, dann klappt das!â€œ). Panik als Dauermodus (â€Die Welt brennt, wir mÃ¼ssen sofort handeln â€“ auÃŸer, wenn ich zum nÃ¤chsten Event fliege!â€œ). Junge Leute mit utopischen Versprechen einfangen, wÃ¤hrend sie selbst im Luxus lebt. Sie ist der moderne RattenfÃ¤nger von Hameln, nur dass sie statt einer FlÃ¶te einen Twitter-Account und ein ARD-Mikrofon hat. WÃ¤hrend sie mit entrÃ¼cktem Blick und dramatischen Worten die Apokalypse verkÃ¼ndet, marschiert ihre Gefolgschaft in Richtung wirtschaftlicher SelbstzerstÃ¶rung â€“ und klatscht dabei begeistert. Fliegen, Feiern, Fordern â€“ Klima-Aktivismus auf First-Class-Niveau Einer ihrer bekanntesten â€Ausrutscherâ€œ war die Diskussion um ihre eigenen Flugreisen. WÃ¤hrend sie anderen vorschreibt, dass Fliegen bÃ¶se ist, jettete sie selbst frÃ¶hlich durch die Weltgeschichte. Ihre Antwort? â€Ich hatte ja keine Wahl.â€œ Genau. Weil es ja auch keine ZÃ¼ge gibt. Oder Videokonferenzen. Oder einen Funken Konsequenz in ihren eigenen Forderungen. Neubauer lebt in einem Widerspruchskosmos, in dem fÃ¼r sie selbst andere Regeln gelten als fÃ¼r die â€dummen Massenâ€œ. WÃ¤hrend sie sich an Kohlekraftwerken festklebt, um â€die Zukunft zu rettenâ€œ, mÃ¼ssen normale BÃ¼rger schauen, wie sie mit explodierenden Energiepreisen klarkommen. GrÃ¼ne Heuchelei auf hÃ¶chstem Niveau Neubauer ist die Inkarnation der grÃ¼nen Doppelmoral. Von Reemtsma-Geld profitieren, aber Kapitalismus abschaffen wollen. Fliegen, aber Flugreisen fÃ¼r andere verteufeln. GrÃ¼nen Kommunismus fordern, aber selbst luxuriÃ¶s leben. WÃ¤hrend sie den Untergang der Welt predigt, macht sie sich ihre eigene Zukunft goldgrÃ¼n: BuchvertrÃ¤ge, Medienauftritte, Lobbytreffen â€“ ein Aktivismus, der vor allem einem Zweck dient: ihrer eigenen Karriere. Das Fazit: Klima-Heilige oder clevere GeschÃ¤ftsfrau? Luisa Neubauer ist kein Umweltengel. Sie ist eine perfekt inszenierte PR-Maschine. Ihre Kampagne hat mit echter Wissenschaft oder nachhaltiger Politik so viel zu tun wie ein Tesla mit Umweltschutz â€“ klingt gut, sieht gut aus, ist aber am Ende doch nur Marketing. Die Frage ist: Wie lange lassen sich die Leute noch tÃ¤uschen? content: Reposting for Veterans Day 2025 #Veteransday https://t.co/ZS83AgL0Qm QT @JJRjrESQ: SEVEN FLIGHTS FROM THAILAND - ONE VET'S RETURN â€œWhy are those soldiers in first class?â€ a business passenger on an American Airlines flight from San Francisco Intâ€™l to Oâ€™Hare grumbled. â€œI had to pay for my seat.â€ Joining the first-class cabin were two uniformed U.S. Air Force members discharged that morning, January 25, 1970. The stewardess had escorted them up front under AAâ€™s upgrade policy for returning military. One was Seargeant James Reardon, Sr., and he gladly sat down, saying thank you in a foreign language. At 6â€™1â€, he was down from 180 lbs to 145. * * * This Veteranâ€™s Day note seeks to chronicle a turning point, the days surrounding one Veteranâ€™s discharge, marking the fulfilment of a sacrificial commitment. * * * To get this far, on January 22, 1970, Reardon and other Airmen had taken a C130 cargo plane from Udorn, Thailand AFB to Bangkok (Don Mueang Airport). The returning Airmen ate dinner, staying one night at the Vien Thi Hotel. Next, they boarded a Continental 707, affectionately, the "bird with the big brass assâ€ rather than the airline's slogan. Waiting during a 10-hour engine change, Reardon counseled a frustrated Army soldier, â€œyou donâ€™t want to be over the ocean if this goes out.â€ He had seen a few planes skid off the Udorn runway. On January 23, 1970, the freedom bird back to â€œthe Worldâ€ took off Easterly, refueling in the Philippines, Guam, and Hawaii, landing on the 24th at Travis AFB, San Francisco. Expected to take up to 3 nights in unaccommodating â€œtransient Airmenâ€ barracks, he learned at 5 am they would be discharged on January 25. While Reardonâ€™s papers were initially missing, he was third or fourth out. The Air Force gave a speech about not being able to enlist for 90 days: some groaned and some cried with laughter. With $700 for remaining pay and a flight, from Travis, you were on your own. Leaving Travis AFB, he and some other Airmen took a cab to San Francisco Int'l to find flights. He was able to book a standby flight to Chicago Oâ€™Hare with no time to call home. From San Francisco, Reardon enjoyed the warm towel and first-class meal. At Oâ€™Hare, he needed to find another standby ticket to Hartford. He called his wife to say he would arrive at Bradley at midnight. Reardonâ€™s parents, 13 y/o sister, wife and son headed in anticipation to Bradley. It was snowing and the sidewalks were like glass. Waiting at the arrival gate, midnight came and went and they were hearing the plane was cancelled. They began to leave, when they heard a page over the intercom. "Paging Beth Reardon.â€ Reardon told her that he was at Logan. The plane had been diverted on its descent. He also told her that a bus was to take him to Springfield, which turned out to be incorrect. Unaware, the welcome party packed up taking an icy Route 91 North to the Springfield bus station. Reardon took a seat on the bus, and was now told it would go to Bradleyâ€”no stops. The driver refused to stop anywhere along the way, invoking Reardonâ€™s ire, who stepped off to hitchhike in the snowfall. He found a convenience store, took a cardboard box and a marker and wrote, â€œSpringfield.â€ The dress uniform wasnâ€™t much comfort in the coldâ€”though much better than his lightweight 1505â€™s. AA had lost his luggage, a heavy blue B4 duffel. The first ride took him to the entrance ramps of the toll booths of the Mass. Pike. In the meantime, his family gave up on the bus, and headed home. Next, a pickup truck, with a friendly man took him to the Palmer rest area, now closed. From a pay phone, he called his brother Raymond, a steamfitter, who in his signature gravelly voice said, â€œI knew I would have to come and get you.â€ Now 3:30 am Monday, Reardon responded, â€œIf you canâ€™t give me a ride, give me someone elseâ€™s phone number.â€ Ray met him at 5 a.m. Heading West and getting off old Exit 4 (now 45), passing the Turnpike sign with a Pilgrim hat with an arrow through it, they were home, almost. He was still â€œkeyed upâ€, being 12 hours ahead. Instead of going directly home, they went to Uncle Milties in Holyoke for coffee. He wanted a moment to acclimate before re-entering civilian atmosphere. Reardon took a table and brother Ray went to the counter. The clerk was pointing in Seargeant Reardonâ€™s direction. Ray told him the clerk wants to know why you are in uniform. â€œReally, I am in the Air Force. Thatâ€™s why.â€ His mother had told him his return should be low key in part because of the anti-war â€œpeople.â€ Ray let him out at the apartment. He could not believe the snow banks. He had not met his 7-month-old daughter, and his son (born while Reardon was stationed at Dover AFB) was now 21 months. True, the Airforce had offered a visit when his daughter was born; he was not sure he would be able to go back. His wife, who had moved in with her conservative Jewish parents during the 11-month Udorn tour, had set up their new apartment. The dining room would serve as the second bedroom with saloon doors between the living room. Weekly rent was $12.50, with a budget to the penny on a new nurseâ€™s salary. His wife also had taken care of his community college applications. Walking up the stairs, his wife came down from the third floor to meet him on that fateful second floor landing. Crying, she had slept in the red dress from the night before so she would have it on when he arrived. His mother and sister had slept on the couch. He took a bath and slept for 10 hours. When he woke up, he met his daughter, and his son didnâ€™t recognize him. In two days, classes started. The B4 bag ultimately was delivered. A day late, they had a small welcome home party. Traditional Irish hors d'ouevres, potato chips and onion dip. Seven flights for cold beer and kielbasa. Coming home to the World. It was perfect. * * * In the first hours of his return, this honorably discharged member of the Air Force experienced interactions of gratefulness, jealousy, helpfulness, and disdain. Today, many take the service of Veterans for granted. As for that first-class seat, rest assured, it wasnâ€™t free. After 4 years, it was earned. #VeteransDay2024 #happyveteransday #VeteransDay #thankaveteran #ThankYouVeterans

content: Yes itâ€™s satirical but thatâ€™s the thing with satire, it pokes fun at the truth. There are a great many people just as insane as portrayed here. https://t.co/jviaHephIS QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Muskâ€™s Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRISÂ²? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost â‚¬50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: @timjcarden British Airways First Class Chicago to London circa 2008 (never used them since). Impressions. Cabin dirty. Attendants ugly, arrogant and rude. Chief Seward, some sweaty middle aged guy wandering around with a â€œwho do you think you are just because you can afford to be hereâ€ attitude with a hospital eye bandage. This was after they decided that seniority of years in cabin attendants resulted in the privilege to work First Class because eye candy was sexist and culturally inappropriate. Contrast Emirates First Class of the same period. Beautiful young woman in traditional dress puts on a show of serving traditional Arabic coffee. Rest of the trip goes just as well as expected. Ambassadorial impression of UAE (+1 cultured and intriguing). Great Britain (-1 probably a dump). British Airways response: Pandering multicultural paint scheme ğŸ˜‚.

content: There nothing a hungry man will not do for relevance just to feed. https://t.co/0yuIyts20K QT @renoomokri: Dear Nedu, Thank you for your thoughts on Lukumi Yoruba street food. However, you need to get out more. Travel to widen the state of your consciousness. Lukumi street food is the most popular and widely accepted cuisine from any Black society on Earth. Let's start with Akara, which means 'I count' (Aka) and then 'I buy' (ra). Please fact-check me: Akara is the most popular street food in Brazil and Cuba and is also one of the most widely accepted street foods in Nigeria. In Brazil, it is known as Akaraje, which means 'I count' (Aka), 'I buy' (ra), and 'I eat' (je). Then, you have Olele, which the Lukumi nicknamed Moin-moin. Moin-moin is now served globally as a breakfast dish because of its high protein and slow digestion, which makes it filling and lasting. Another Lukumi Yoruba street food is Dodo Ikire. It originated from Ikire in Osun State, but with the British colonisation of Nigeria, it spread to Lagos and environs, where it simply became known as Dodo. This fried plantain dish is one of the most popular street foods in the Caribbean, where it was taken by the Lukumi enslaved people. From there, it has become world famous and is today even served to First Class passengers on British Airways as a delicacy. Akara, Moin-moin, and dodo are so good and delicious that they are now the most popular street foods in Nigeria's six geopolitical zones. This means that anybody who insults Lukumi Yoruba cuisine also insults their own ethnicity, which also prefers Lukumi street food. Finally, I sponsored an Amala hangout in Enugu last November, which was jam-packed. I can send you photos. The media covered it. If Amala is as nasty as you depict, the hangout wouldn't have been a success. Nedu, I am telling you and those who think like you all these things to make you understand that if any street food puts Nigeria on the map, it is Lukumi Yoruba street food, followed closely by the Hausa delicacy, Suya. As such, it would not be in Nigeria's best interest for you and your ilk to denigrate our cuisine to the world as your insulting and fallacious image depicts. Thanks again, and may God give you wisdom. #TableShaker

content: For 7 years I flew 100,000 miles a year. American Airlines executive platinum was the best thing ever. It literally was the greatest part of my job and is the ONLY thing I miss about my â€œprevious lifeâ€. https://t.co/PBgnHJoum3 QT @TylerPurcell24: I flew first class for the first time recently. (Before anyone one freaks out, this is not a flex, upgrade was under $200) 4.5 hour flight to LA from Cincy. People told me that it would be tough to fly main cabin again. AND itâ€™s true. Made air travel 20x more enjoyable. - Selected our breakfast the night before and was ready when we wanted. - Free drinks and snacks with great service. - Extra room made sitting so much more comfortable. - Feels like youâ€™re not on a commercial flight. Different ambience, music, and divider. - First on and first off For my veteran first class fliers, any tips and tricks? If itâ€™s a long flight and the upgrade is that price, Iâ€™m doing it every time.

content: @GopalBhootra @RajeshShares @luxe_explorer With 40,000 Avios, a round-trip economy flight from Delhi or Mumbai to Kuala Lumpur via Malaysia Airlines (direct, ~29,000 Avios + taxes) is possible. For Bangkok or Singapore, connecting routes (e.g., via Doha on Qatar) may need 45,000â€“50,000 Avios round-trip in economy + taxes, so 40k covers one-way or close. Business class one-way to some SEA spots (like Kuala Lumpur) is around 43,000 Avios. Availability varies; use British Airways' site to check.

Estes Carter Thompson III was caught secretly filming a 14-year-old girl using the bathroom by taping his phone to the back of the toilet. Investigators were shocked to find that Thompson had videos of children (aged 7, 9, 11, & 14) from other flights. Thompson was finally caught after an incident in late 2023. He had noticed a girl was waiting for the bathroom and told her to come with him to the first-class bathroom. Before entering the lavatory, Thompson said he needed to wash his hands. When inside the bathroom, he taped his phone to the seat. The girl didn't notice the phone until she got up. She took a picture to show her mother. (seen below) The mother then told her father who confronted Thompson in the back of the plane where a "kerfuffle" went down, according to the family's lawyer. Thompson faces up to 20 years in prison for child exploitation. A massive trove of child p*rn was also found on his electronic devices.

content: @akaNemsko @HansMokeNiemann Sure, akaNemsko! Here's Hans's story reformatted with paragraph breaks for easier reading: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.

content: To add to this, Atoyebi phoned BA upon landing and they later informed him that his luggage was found. content: @Wildingarden @Rainmaker1973 The $21M is American Airlines' estimated total cost over 21 years (1987-2008), averaging ~$1M/year in lost revenue from unsold first-class seats, taxes, fees, and miles redeemed. With 10k+ flights (often with companions or empty seats booked), it equates to about $2,100 per flight in opportunity cost. He got immense value from his $400k investment (pass + companion).
